talk.start.para: —by leave—On behalf of the government parties, and also Senator Ridgeway and the Australian Democrats, I move:

speech.para: That the Senate:
(a) reaffirms its whole-hearted commitment to the cause of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians as an important national priority for all Australians;

(b) recognising the achievements of the Australian nation, commits to work together to strengthen the bonds that unite us, to respect and appreciate our differences, and to build a fair and prosperous future in which we can all share;

(c) reaffirms the central importance of practical measures leading to practical results that address the profound economic and social disadvantage which continues to be experienced by many indigenous Australians;
(d) recognises the importance of understanding the shared history of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians and the need to acknowledge openly the wrongs and injustices of Australia's past;
(e) acknowledges that the mistreatment of many indigenous Australians over a significant period represents the most blemished chapter in our national history;

(f) expresses its deep and sincere regret that indigenous Australians suffered injustices under the practices of past generations, and for the hurt and trauma that many indigenous people continue to feel as a consequence of those practices; and
(g) believes that we, having achieved so much as a nation, can now move forward together for the benefit of all Australians.

I am pleased to move this motion on behalf of the Liberal Party and the National Party and jointly with the Australian Democrats. I have to say that I am disappointed that the Australian Labor Party was not prepared to join in co-sponsoring the motion.

If the late Neville Bonner were here today, he would obviously be supporting this motion. When he gave us advice, as he so often did, on indigenous matters, he used to say that he believed we were listening but often felt that we did not hear. The message that he used to seek to give us was that you cannot address the disadvantages of Aboriginal people, which are acknowledged by all, without understanding and recognising the causes of those disadvantages; in other words, without understanding the effects of loss of land, loss of culture, loss of language and loss of identity.

This motion seeks to take a step along what we concede to be a long and difficult path of true reconciliation—to recognise, through this form, that Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders have suffered in this way and that we need as a people to understand the effects and consequences of that suffering and to genuinely express regret for it if we are going to effectively address the contemporary disadvantages from which indigenous peoples still suffer. This government recognises that fact and hopes, as I said, that this motion is a step along that path.

As you know, Madam President, we have sought as a government to place greater emphasis upon the practical ways in which we can address the disadvantages that are so well known. We put great emphasis on issues of Aboriginal housing, health, education and jobs. I think there have been some successes, but we recognise by this motion that it cannot be done without linking it to the past and to the causes of those disadvantages. We hope that this recognition today is therefore seen and accepted by Aboriginal people as a genuine attempt to be able to move on while recognising the causes of the disadvantage. In other words, it is an attempt to build respect. It is a statement of respect out of what I hope is now a better understanding of the real causes of Aboriginal disadvantage.

I am conscious of the fact that there are many senators who want to associate themselves with this statement today and, therefore, I should speak briefly. However, I do want to say—and previously I said it deliberately—that I see this as a step along the road. It is not as though reconciliation is starting today. There have been individual Australians and communities within Australia who have been constructively contributing to reconciliation for a long period of time. I think we should recognise and appreciate those who have so tried for so long. To mention Neville Bonner is to give just one example of such an Australian.

There have been good stories in the past. Perhaps not often enough do we recall the good stories; we tend to dwell upon the failures and the disappointments. But we are all part of this community. It is a community that is enriched by Aboriginal culture and we need, as I said, to respect that as a step along this road of reconciliation.

I want to pay particular credit today to the Prime Minister, who has been prepared to show leadership in this area with this motion and also to acknowledge with thanks the work of Senator Ridgeway. It is somewhat symbolic to think of a negotiation of a set of words between such a senior politician as the Prime Minister and a new politician in this place, between an indigenous Australian and a non-indigenous Australian. Perhaps the symbolism of that will help us along the path of reconciliation as well.

Lastly, I want to pay tribute to Senator Herron who is often, in this place anyway, not given the credit he deserves. He has worked diligently and effectively within Aboriginal communities to advance their interests in the constructive and practical ways which have been the emphasis of this government, areas such as health, education, housing and jobs. It is unfortunate that this resolution has been called on on a day when Senator Herron is not in the chamber because I know he would have wanted the opportunity to speak to and to associate himself with this motion.
I commend the motion to the Senate. I hope in the end it gets the unanimous support of the Senate.

talk.start.para: —This motion is, tragically, a second-best motion. That is a sad thing to have to admit. When the stolen generations report was released in May 1997, there was drafted, and the Senate eventually passed, a resolution that provided exactly what was required—a proper apology. Most state parliaments followed suit with not a formal expression of regret but an apology that was heartfelt and unreserved—except one. That is an interesting story in itself. In Queensland, the National Party was in power and Rob Borbidge took exception to a decent apology. So the Nationals moved one of their own. It said:

speech.para: I move that the Parliament of Queensland, on behalf of the people of Queensland, expresses its sincere regret for the personal hurt suffered by those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who, in the past, were unjustifiably removed from their families.
That was the Borbidge government's response. I think Senator Ridgeway last night called it `by far the worst' of the states' responses. But that is the response that we have here, that this Senate:

expresses its deep and sincere regret that indigenous Australians suffered injustices under the practices of past generations, and for the hurt and trauma that many indigenous people continue to feel as a consequence of those practices;
At the time of the Borbidge motion, Peter Beattie, as opposition leader, moved an amendment which contained a decent apology. He moved:
That this House:

(1) apologises to the Aboriginal people on behalf of all Queenslanders for the past policies under which Aboriginal children were forcibly separated from their families and expresses deep sorrow and regret at the hurt and distress that this caused . . .

Decency came to Queensland last year. Peter Beattie as Premier was able to move his amendment. `Regret' moved to `unreserved apology', and deep sorrow about Queensland's past treatment of Aborigines was expressed on behalf of the people of Queensland. So we move our amendment today. I move:
Omit paragraph (f), substitute:

(f) unreservedly apologises to indigenous Australians for the injustice they have suffered, and for the hurt and trauma that many indigenous people continue to suffer as a consequence of that injustice;

(fa) calls for the establishment of appropriate processes to provide justice and restitution to members of the stolen generation through consultation, conciliation and negotiation rather than requiring indigenous Australians to engage in adversarial litigation in which they are forced to relive the pain and trauma of their past suffering;
We move that with the express purpose of one day seeing it stand in the Hansard as a government motion. We move it because the motion we have now before the chamber is second best.

There has been much said about who supports this motion among the Aboriginal community. But I think it is fair to say that not one of the people in the Aboriginal community who support this motion would not prefer a better one. I can understand why people have supported second best when the alternative is nothing at all. But we would do well to remember why that was the only choice. The whole point of the government motion is to settle the issue—and this does not. That is the whole point: it is to settle the issue. The motion we have before us does not settle the issue. It is not about the thousands of members of the stolen generations; it is about one person—the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. The tragedy of this is that what should be a matter of national healing—the national psychology—has become a matter of a Prime Minister saving face and keeping his back covered. That is the saddest aspect of this second-best motion.

Because the semantics have shifted and weakened the intent that millions of Australians wish for, the apology has slipped into the unedifying ruck of politics. It has become a newsprint plaything, part of the endless `who's up, who's down; who's in, who's out; who's negotiating, who isn't negotiating'. That is not the stuff—and this is not the stuff—of national psychology or national honour. There is no honour in the motion. And it will cost us as a nation.

This year's budget papers state that there are 2,200 claims by members of the stolen generations under way. They say the Commonwealth could potentially be liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in compensation. The Commonwealth has already spent several millions of dollars fighting the first of the stolen generations' litigants in the Northern Territory. It has created pain, anger and mistrust in the process. We all know that the greatest cost to the taxpayer will be incurred if the stolen generations' claims are all litigated individually. The only way to deal with this is through a transparent, honest process beginning with a decent apology and building goodwill into the compensation process. This compensation will come anyway. Why can it not be done in a way which promotes healing rather than anger and, incidentally, costs the Commonwealth less? I commend to the Senate the amendment that I have moved on behalf of the opposition. I believe that it would be appropriate for the Senate to give its sentiments strong endorsement today.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Australian Democrats and as the co-sponsor of the motion by the Hon. Senator Robert Hill. I note the matters that have been put by Senator John Faulkner, although I cannot support what it is that has been expressed. I want to first say that I welcome the motion as presented by Senator Hill. It is a motion that so many Australians, I believe, have waited for patiently and with the certainty that it would come before the Australian parliament. In my heart, I thought that this day may have come much later than this, and I would like to give credit to the government for the journey that it has taken in a short period of time.

speech.para: I do not want to revisit many of the things that I had spoken about in my first speech last night, but I do repeat the need for consenting reconciliation. I think that these words hold particular meaning today, because it is so crucial that this motion is wholeheartedly supported and endorsed by the House of Representatives and the Senate. I have agonised over this for quite some time and there has been no pleasure in that. A person that I took personal counsel and advice from on this issue, a member of the stolen generations and an indigenous leader who is highly respected, Dr Lowitja O'Donoghue, said this morning that this motion is really about healing for the stolen generations and for the healing of the nation. It has nothing to do with politics. It has a far deeper and greater meaning.' So, like Dr O'Donoghue, I am appealing for a multipartisan approach from the Senate.

In considering the motion it is important to point out that it has been arrived at through consultation and discussions with other indigenous leaders—and I accept that there may be other views expressed by others. I want to talk about some of the comments that these people have made. This morning I received comments from the ATSIC chairman, Gatjil Djerrkura. He asked me to present his message about his views on this motion:
I have read the possible draft motion and discussed this matter with Senator Ridgeway.

I have made it clear that first and foremost the words and the sentiments of the proposed motion of the national parliament must be acceptable to those who suffered, and who continue to suffer as a result of past practices and policies.
He said:
I believe the proposed motion moves the debate on a national apology along and I believe those involved should be acknowledged for their efforts in this regard.
But I repeat. . . the form of words finally settled upon by the parliament must be acceptable to members of the stolen generations.
It must be acknowledged that the mistreatment of many indigenous Australians over a significant period of time represents the most blemished chapter in our national history.
He said:
This has been accepted in all state parliaments.
It should now be recognised by our national parliament.
He also went on to say:
This is not a small matter for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. It should not be a small matter for the national parliament.

He says he will be watching the progress of this debate closely and consulting with his fellow commissioners and other indigenous leaders as this unfolds. I also spoke to Evelyn Scott, the Chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Her comments were:
. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation welcomes this motion with an open heart and open arms.
. This is a great day for reconciliation in our country.
. This motion reflects the broad-ranging aims of reconciliation that the Council has been striving to get across to the nation.
. If adopted by parliament, these words will impart tremendous new momentum to the reconciliation process.

. I am confident that all Australians can now move forward together to make reconciliation a reality in the everyday life of our communities, workplaces, organisations and institutions, as outlined in the Council's Draft Document for Reconciliation currently being discussed across the nation.

Again, I return to comments by Dr Lowitja O'Donoghue. She said, before I came into this chamber, `I believe the coalition has come a long way in relation to the stolen generations.' She said, `I am on my own journey of healing and I believe the Prime Minister has embarked on a similar one. The matter is really about healing for the stolen generations and healing for the nation. It has nothing to do with politics. It has a far deeper and greater meaning. `And she appeals for a multipartisan approach from the Australian parliament.

For my own views in relation to this matter, as much as I accept what Senator John Faulkner has said, one of the points I made in my first speech last night was that one of the greatest obstacles to reconciliation in this country has always been that of fear. I took a leaf out of the book of a person I respect immensely who is known the world over: President Nelson Mandela, the former President of South Africa. He made the point many years ago that, in order to begin to deal with their truth and reconciliation in South Africa, they needed to remove white fear. Whilst we may not agree with the words that are presented and whilst we may not agree with the sentiments that are expressed, I think we need to understand that this house does not just represent the political views of political parties; it represents the views of the nation. In that nation there is fear. It is a fear held by many people about what it is that indigenous people are striving to achieve. In terms of reconciliation and making it a national issue, rather than just an indigenous issue, it is as much about removing that fear in order to give comfort about what reconciliation means.

I support the motion being put for that very reason. It is not second best, nor is it a compromise. It is an understanding of the fear that exists in the hearts and minds of many Australians. It is an understanding of the suffering, hurt and trauma experienced by so many indigenous people and their desire to have proper recognition. But this is not the end of that recognition; this is the beginning of a process. It should lead to reconciliation coming to every person in this nation as a stranger and, when it departs from us, it should leave us as friends.

I make one final plea, and that is that the opposition supports the motion that is being put forward and that it rises above party political consideration. There must be an acknowledgment of the fear that is held by many other Australians and there must be an attempt to grapple with what reconciliation means. These are the small and easy steps in the process of reconciliation; the hard yards are yet to be done. We must move forward by removing the crucial obstacle that prevents us from getting to the document of reconciliation. I leave that before this Senate.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the Senate is debating the motion of reconciliation today. Before I continue with my contribution, may I congratulate Senator Ridgeway not only for his first speech last night but also for his contribution just now. It came to me whilst I heard him speaking that he has been here three or four weeks and he has probably lifted the Aboriginal profile to its highest level of any time. He is to be congratulated.

speech.para: The National Party is committed to reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. Our way is to do what is suggested in part (b) of the motion—that is, to build a fair and prosperous future in which we can all share. The National Party way is to encourage industry in rural and regional areas so that jobs are created for both black and white Australians, and Australians in the bush and in the cities can benefit from the wealth that comes from industry and exports. The National Party is also very concerned that there be practical measures to address disadvantages wherever they may be found in Australia. Unless indigenous health, education and employment standards improve, in another 50 years and at another time another group of senators may well be apologising for our lack of action today.

The National Party represents the bush. It is in the bush that black and white Australians have really shared their lives with each other. They have grown up together, gone to the same schools, played on the same teams, worked side by side in the mills or on the council gangs and worked as ringers on the stations. We were reminded today by Senator Crane that he had sheared in teams with Aboriginals. Together we must take care to strengthen those bonds, because those Australians out there must live out what we in this chamber profess today. While there are blemishes on our national character, there are also people who strove against the injustices and did the right thing. This time it is important to be positive. There is a momentum in the country which demands this action today. However, I am mindful that we do not carry all Australians with us, and that is something to which we must pay attention, and something that Senator Ridgeway alluded to in his speech.

This motion affirms Australia as an inclusive society, so it is important that we come to grips with continuing fears and uncertainties over native title claims. If we do not, we risk souring the seeds of reconciliation which we have sown today. Reconciliation is about all of us as a nation. It is not about asking rural land-holders to bear the burden alone. I acknowledge that there were mistreatments and injustices and that the hurt and trauma continue to affect lives today in our indigenous society.

We like to take pride in our national heritage; what we have achieved, the kind of society that developed and where we hope to be in the future. But if we are honest, we must also look at the flip side of that pride and we just cannot blot it out. It is time that we as a nation acknowledge not only the pride but also the inequities that we inflicted on the first Australians. That is what we are doing today to try and set the record straight so that we can get on with the job of nation building. The National Party fervently hopes, as stated in paragraph (g) of the motion, that we can now move forward together for the benefit of all Australians.

I hope that today is a new beginning for all of us, black and white, and that this is the time when we draw together in order to move forward as a nation. There are so many common goals in rural areas, and yet so many common disadvantages. We need to develop industry across the nation. We need the mines, dams, bridges and pipelines that make jobs and we need to build roads. We need more education and health services and also to underwrite small business in rural and remote areas for the benefit of all—black and white. Development will put back all the services the bush has lost. All families, black and white, will benefit. Aboriginal leaders are as concerned over the lack of infrastructure and employment and the resultant welfare dependency in the bush as white leaders.

There exists a common bond but, whereas before the two were pushing away from each other, we signal today that there must be a drawing together. Let us hope that this expression today sets the stage for making that common bond highly visible, tangible and mutually beneficial.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak in this debate and, in doing so, express concern at what is before us this afternoon. There is no greater social issue facing this nation than reconciliation. There is no greater stain on our history than how we have treated our indigenous people, and there will be no greater hurdle to Australia's future than how we overcome the problems of indigenous Australians.

speech.para: This is a defining moment in Australia's history and, as a defining moment, it should reflect the values of magnanimity, inclusiveness, dignity, decency and honesty. We should as a nation, as a parliament, as a government and as a prime minister be big enough to address the stains of the past with the maturity that our present and future demand. Australians are surely big enough to not only be proud of our achievements but also acknowledge our failures and acknowledge such failures with honesty—to front the truth.

As a defining moment in our history, this moment is not a moment for words of avoidance. This is not a moment for trickiness or sneakiness. This is not a moment for the politics, aspirations and values of the lowest common denominator. At this moment in our history, as we face the new millennium and as we face unprecedented international attention on Australia, we should be big enough to say one word, and that word is `sorry'. The words before us today are not the words that will put this issue to rest. The people behind those words know that full well.
Let us acknowledge sincerely and honestly that, as Pamela Bone said in this morning's Melbourne Age:
Aboriginal people bear all the signs of an underclass because since the beginning of white settlement they have been treated as an underclass.
She quotes the Director of VicHealth, Dr Rob Moodie, who recently said:

If people are told they're no good for long enough and it's repeated generation after generation, it profoundly affects them, no matter who they are. Discrimination causes ill health, there's no doubt about it.

What we are doing once again today is something which I think continues that discrimination. We are denying the enormity of the injustice of the past, and we are continuing that discrimination because we are not prepared as a government and as a parliament to offer to indigenous Australians what we continue to offer and have offered to others on whom we perpetrate injustices, and that is an open and generous apology.

Instead of a statement of principle, what we have today is an escape clause for a Prime Minister who will not confront the reality of the past and who has a blinkered view of the past. That is what we have got here today: the Prime Minister standing out against the tide of all decent Australians who want an apology. What we have from him today is an escape clause.

We are defining our history. What we are talking about here is not something as the motion states. These are not actions of former generations that we are talking about, and I am sure Senator Ridgeway is amongst those who know that. These are not merely the actions of former generations; these are the actions of the Prime Minister's generation and even to some extent the generation that comes after him, my generation.

Yesterday Senator Ridgeway told us that, of the apologies across the country and across the parliaments, the Queensland response was the worst. It is the Borbidge Queensland response which merely goes so far as to express regret. That is what made it the worst yesterday. Why is an apology which was the worst yesterday acceptable today to the national parliament? Why are the words that yesterday were acknowledged by Senator Ridgeway as reflecting the worst of apologies across the states acceptable to this parliament, which has a national responsibility for indigenous affairs? It has got to be asked, Senator Ridgeway: why are those words good enough, and hasn't the cause in some respects been sold short?

I have before me a letter from Mick Dodson, a person who was quite critical of the whole awareness raising of this issue and the Bringing them home report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. He expresses bitter disappointment. He says:

I guess the stolen generations will be bitterly disappointed by Mr Howard's incapacity. Paragraph (f) as presently drafted lets Mr Howard off the hook. It is undoubtedly the place where an unambiguous apology should go. Why is it so hard?
That is the question we have to ask ourselves. Why was it so hard for the Prime Minister? Mick Dodson says:

The proposed motion falls well short of the mark even on the fairest reading of it. The Indigenous individuals the recommendation speaks of are the Stolen Generations. They, their families and communities are invisible in this proposed motion.
History will show that over the last three decades this is the only Australian Prime Minister who has not been prepared to say and do the decent thing.

Let us place that on the record. All others who have held that high position in our nation and system of government have been big enough; they have had the magnanimity of leadership to do it. Gough Whitlam is on the record, Malcolm Fraser is on the record, Bob Hawke is on the record, Paul Keating is on the record, and even John Hewson is on the record. He did not make the prime ministership, but he was a leader of the Liberal Party. All of them expressed the fundamental decency which is integral to the Australian character—that is, to give others a fair go, to treat them fairly and to say sorry.

Madam President, the Labor Party would rather be addressing a motion which better reflects the injustices and better reflects the magnanimity of Australian people. Opportunities have been lost over the last few years. What we should be focused on here today is the chance to seize the moment and seize the opportunities for the future. As Mick Dodson says, the families who are most affected by the stolen generations have not really been involved in the evolution and definition of what is before this parliament.

This is a belated half-hearted attempt to address the issue. We are committed to a full and unreserved apology to indigenous Australians for the injustice they have suffered, and we are also committed to an honest recollection of our history. As I said, this is something that has involved generations who are in this parliament, not former generations, and this is something that really needs—for the moment, for Australia's definition of history—a lot more magnanimity and not an escape clause.

talk.start.para: —I welcome this motion of reconciliation because of its positive tone and its commitment to the future. We must all respond to the views of our electorate constituencies, and within those constituencies there are many groups and subgroups. Probably the most important interest group on this issue to me in the Northern Territory electorate is my own family. My son, Coryn, has very strong and positive views on this issue. He has certainly been arguing with and attempting to influence me profoundly in the last year or so, and I think the tenor of his comments is very obvious in this motion.

speech.para: My daughter, Amalia, has very strong views about the community in which she lives and what she sees of the future. But, probably more importantly, their cousins—Aaron, Stephen and Tammy Abala—have much more at stake, because they have an Aboriginal heritage. I believe this motion will bring together the comments and the aspirations of many of those cousins.

From this day forward, it is important that we remove the politically correct tokenism that so many people have focused on in the past and the corners of the boxing ring to which we have all been drawn. The time for mouthing platitudes is past, and we must speak realistically not only about the problems we face but also about their causes and their solutions.

Perhaps the most important phrase in the motion is that we `respect and appreciate our differences'. Respect is vital for reconciliation and appreciation of someone else's culture. I think we have achieved this respect and appreciation in the Northern Territory to a greater degree than elsewhere in Australia. The differences in society are very obvious, and the differences within Aboriginal society are also equally important to note. There are huge differences between Aboriginal communities in remote, isolated, traditional living environments in the Northern Territory and those on the east coast.

Reconciliation is more than white Australians apologising to black Australians for past wrongs and injustices. It is about all Australians respecting, accepting and acknowledging each other's cultures and lifestyles and, importantly, introducing love into the equation. In all of the debates that I have heard on this issue, it is very obvious that from time to time we do not talk about how we express or how we convey love and, sadly, I think that that has been the missing part of the equation for the last few years.

In Darwin, a city of almost 100,000 people, we have a very unique blending and interacting of cultures. What is often described, by some who come from elsewhere in Australia, as a laid-back lifestyle is in fact an accepting one. We in Darwin, and most other parts of the Territory, accept the rights of other people to live as they like. We respect others' cultures and admire what they have to offer us. The Territory is unique, I believe, in the way that its residents have adopted aspects of other cultures to complement their own.

Ten years ago I spoke at a function in Darwin. I looked around the room and said that, in 10 or 20 years, most of the people in that room would have someone of Aboriginal background and someone of Asian background in their family. It is absolutely amazing and deeply satisfying to me to see the number of people who have now stopped me in the street to say that that prediction has come true. I say `satisfying' because it shows how truly accepting and multicultural people in Australia are.

Importantly, the motion we are debating acknowledges that our past history contains some unsavoury and ghastly experiences which produced unacceptable practices and consequences. We must know that, still today, the sins of our fathers are visited on too many Aboriginal Australians and other Australians.

In 1967 this parliament instituted an important referendum which drew a line in the sand on Aboriginal rights and involvement in the Australian nation. That was over 30 years ago, and much has happened. There are still a lot of areas where our priorities, our dealings and our attention to detail was not good enough in those 30 years. In the last couple of years we have had very intense debates in this parliament with regard to indigenous rights, specifically with regard to land.

All of those issues now, I believe, are very comprehensively accepted, are in place and are part of the law and the culture of Australia. But it is important that the motion today now draws another line in the sand. By drawing a line in the sand we can now look to at least the next 30 years—hopefully, for most of us in this place—and ask: what will be our commitment; what will be the influence we want to have; what will be the priorities we will determine; and what will be, at a government level, the programs and the policies that we will institute and adopt to put our personal commitments into place?

One of my colleagues in a party room debate yesterday pointed out very clearly that true reconciliation can only take place in our homes and in our living rooms. It is only when I have a backyard barbecue, as I did last Sunday night with my nephews and niece, that you get that very proper aspect of reconciliation that is so important. There is so much to commend this motion because of what it offers the future.

talk.start.para: —I support Labor's amendment to this motion. That is what we should be voting on in the house today. We should be voting for the full and unreserved apology which the stolen generation deserves, and ultimately must have and will have from a more enlightened and representative Prime Minister at some time further down the line.

speech.para: The problem here is the smallness of the Prime Minister, his inability to rise to the required words of, `I am sorry on behalf of the nation,' which is going to be the end point of this inevitable process. They are words, but they are important words. This halfway house of regrets that we have is simply part of a process towards somebody else doing what our Prime Minister fails to do on behalf of this nation.

I have a heavy heart and regrets about the fact that it is the indigenous people who are having to give again. After two centuries, on a matter that is symbolic like this, it required giving by the indigenous people for the Prime Minister to be able to get what essentially he wanted to be able to be accommodated in this matter. We are really marking time along the road to a much more mature and dignified and essential outcome, which is the national expression of sorrow which has been able to be put forward in all state jurisdictions now.

Yesterday, Senator Ridgeway did point to Queensland as having the worst expression, which was one of regret, and here we are with that worst level as far as states are concerned. He also mentioned that the Apple Isle, Tasmania, had the best expression. It was put forward by the Greens, the Labor Party and by then Premier Rundle, who moved the motion back in 1997. I want to read that because it is very brief. It is what we should be supporting here today. The motion was:
That this parliament on behalf of all Tasmanians—
read Australians there—

expresses its deep and sincere regrets at the hurt and distress caused by past policies under which Aboriginal children were removed from their families and homes, apologises to the Aboriginal people for those past actions, and reaffirms its support for reconciliation between all Australians.
That is what we should be supporting here today, and I support the Labor amendment because it brings us in line with that direct sentiment.

Senator Ridgeway said that this house represents the views of the nation. In effect, it represents the diversity of views in the nation. If it is going to do that adequately it has to be able to consult with its constituencies. I, for one, have not had time to contact my constituency, let alone the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre, to get feedback on what it thinks about this form of words. So I, as a representative, feel inadequate to this task. I do not feel it is my place to be able to judge on this matter without the Aboriginal community in my home state having considered and been given the time to discuss the matter. So, having the motion suddenly before the chamber at a bit after noon today, with no prior warning as far as I am concerned, and with no approach to see whether the Greens would co-sponsor the motion, defeats that purpose of it being truly representative of the views of the people whom we represent in this place.

With those words, I say as a stage along the road that I am not going to do anything but support every move in that direction. But my heart is full of regret that the Prime Minister has not given this nation the words that ultimately it must express. We are here in a process, and we have not found our way home in this matter.

talk.start.para: —The topic of reconciliation and the treatment of the stolen generation has been on the national stage for many years, but it seems as if in the last 24 hours it has well and truly had the spotlight put on it. Similar to my colleague, Senator Brown, I ask why I learnt of this move by the government to put this motion before the Senate less than some two hours ago.

speech.para: Coming from the Northern Territory, where a third of the population are indigenous, I certainly have not had any time to contact indigenous leaders in the territory in either the north or the south—people like Mr Tilmouth or Galarrwuy Yunupingu and leaders in that area—to get a feel for what they think about this. I ask myself: why are we suddenly standing here today debating or even looking at this motion? What has actually changed in this government in the last couple of hours, or days? What has brought about a change of heart from the Prime Minister? Has it been the change in the composition of people who are before us in the Senate today?

I hear what Senator Ridgeway says about Dr O'Donoghue's comments, but there is a part of me that cannot help think that this is all about politics, that this is all about the government now realising that not an awful lot of their legislation is going to get through this chamber unless they walk beside the Democrats. So, I am feeling somewhat suspicious that without most indigenous leaders in this country having had a chance to look at this, and without people who come into this parliament representing indigenous Austral ians having had the chance to take it back to their states or territories either, this cannot be anything but politics.

The Howard government today is where I think it should have been three years ago when it took office. The debate we are having today should have been around three years ago. Whether we say `regret', whether we say `we apologise' or whether we say the word `sorry' should have been out there in the ether for Australians and indigenous Australians to talk about. But it has been written and it has been documented in the Bringing them home report. So let us cast our minds back to three months ago and this year's Sorry Day. We have organisations who have not been afraid to use that word. We had National Sorry Day. And, just three months ago, this government and this Prime Minister were not prepared to make the step that they have made today.

The actions of this government are not under debate today; I do not think their policies or their decisions are in the limelight and it is not appropriate that we go into them. But when we talk about standing in this chamber and representing all Australians, diverse Australians, as Senator Brown said, there are very, very many of us out there who actually want to see the word `sorry' or `apology' in any motion this government puts through. So, no, this motion does not represent what Australians want. There are very, very many of us out there who want to hear this government and want to be part of this parliament apologising to the stolen generations. If the word `sorry' is not good enough—and I do not understand why it is not—then `regret' is certainly not good enough. You see, the word `regret' actually brings us down to the lowest common denominator. I do not believe that, as a federal parliament, that is where we should be at. We should be striving, I believe, to reach the highest standards and to offer the best.

I will just say one other thing. This is, as I said back in May, about a journey of reconciliation. This is about us walking beside our indigenous Australians. Once again, we have found that they have walked some of the way and we have walked some of the way, or the Prime Minister has attempted to, but the indigenous Australians have come half way, again. I know they have been met by the Prime Minister and the efforts of this government to reach a compromise. But it is not about indigenous people walking any way, half way or three-quarters of the way. They are down the road. They have suffered the injustices. They have been ignored by this country by virtue of our Constitution, by the fact that it took us nearly 67 years to give them a vote. They have walked the path and they have suffered for that. They do not need to only walk half way here. We need to reach out and embrace what we have been hearing them say for many, many years. We are the ones that need to take this issue all the way. White Australians are the ones that need to reach out and put forward a very strong statement that indigenous Australians have wanted to hear.

My colleague from the Northern Territory talked about words of love being omitted in all of this debate. I will just say this: when you truly love somebody, you are also prepared to say you are sorry to that person. You do not offer regret for your actions or for words that you have said, but you actually open your heart, and when you love someone you are also prepared to say that you are sorry to this person.

I want to place on record that I personally think that this is a start. But it is a start that I think the government and the parliament should be putting out into the public for them to have a look at. This motion should not start and finish in the hour and a half today, in a rush. There is no rush for this. I know it is something that indigenous Australians have wanted for a long time, but it is something that should be out there for people to look at and comment upon.

I recognise the work that Senator Ridgeway has done. I do recognise the work and the steps that the government have taken in this. I do not think it is far enough. I do not think it is what a lot of Australians want. They do want to see this parliament apologise. They do want to see the word `sorry'. I would ask people to support our amendments and then support the motion as a whole.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak to this motion—and I will keep my remarks brief—I would like to begin by congratulating Senator Ridgeway and the Prime Minister for the leadership that they have shown in getting this motion before the Senate, as part of the parliament of Australia, today. I find it rather sad that we can have people criticising the motion on the basis that it has been rushed, that it is not well thought out, that it has not been before the Australian public, because many, if not all, of the Australian public have had on their conscience for a long time the issue of how you can get an acceptable solution that—and I want to raise the word `fear' that Senator Ridgeway put forward—would remove the fear.

speech.para: I am going to say today what I have said before in this place. I grew up in a community where 25 per cent of the people were Aboriginal. In my education, for virtually all my primary school days, there were more Aboriginal children than there were Europeans. In the sporting teams that I played in there were as many or more Aboriginals than there were Europeans. We had a great friendship. We had a great respect. We worked together, we played together, we drank together. And, of course, you come from a different perspective when you have spent your youth in these circumstances. I have also seen the fear—I have seen the fear in the white community and I have seen the fear in the black community. I say to Senator Ridgeway: today, you have touched and brought before this parliament a very important aspect to be overcome to progress reconciliation. I compliment you on that.

I said in the party room earlier today, as Senator Boswell acknowledged, that having grown up during the 1950s, 1960s and the 1970s I acknowledge being a contemporary part of some of the things that we regret did happen. But I was also a part of the good things that happened, and there were many good things. It is always dangerous to mention names, but I am going to acknowledge out of the Moora district a few families, black and white, who were involved in a lot of the good things that happened, because we need to recognise when we are debating these issues that it was not all bad. There were bad parts, but there were also good parts. There are parts that we regret; there are parts which we are very proud of.

The people I want to mention in my contribution in this regard begin with Dr Myles, in Moora. There could not have been a finer doctor in terms of treating all Australians absolutely equally in how he looked after them and what he did, in very difficult circumstances. On the other side, I want to mention the Yappo family, the Narrier family. I shore for about seven or eight years in a team which was basically run by the Narrier family, and I saw what they did, how they worked and how they dealt with a difficult issue. I want to mention Father Basil, a Benedict monk down in New Norcia. The way that he pulled people together and got people working together and doing things is something that should be acknowledged in this debate. It gives us a guiding line as to how we can develop reconciliation, how we can bring people, black and white, back together.

I particularly want to mention my own mother and father, and my grandparents. I have to say quite clearly here that, while I am quite happy to say that I regret, they had nothing to be regretful for. I want to mention the Jackamarra family, the May family, equally Aboriginal families, who did an enormous amount to support a lot of people who were in difficult situations. And, of course, there were many others.

I see this as a very positive way forward. I see this motion as a motion which will come to grips with that component of the fear which does exist. I do not think it is as much as it was a few years ago. I may be wrong on that; I am only making a personal judgment. But I want to re-emphasise that we need to look at the whole perspective of this issue before us. We need to open up our hearts in terms of dealing with some of the difficulties that we will have in the future.

I think if we take forward into the community the spirit of the purpose behind what has been done here, if we show the leadership that is required, as people elected by the people of Australia to represent them in this parliament, this motion can do one hell of a lot toward overcoming some of the difficulties of the past and progressing the future. In this way we can become a much better and more harmonious society, one that we will continue to be proud of. This will go a long way to giving every Australian, whether ethnic, white, black or whatever they might be, a way forward which will make sure that we become a more tolerant and better society.

talk.start.para: —I want to acknowledge the work done by Senator Ridgeway in getting this motion together. I say, though, that the amendments put forward by the opposition best sum up the issues that are at stake here. This motion deals with fundamental issues for indigenous Australians but it deals also with fundamental issues for non-indigenous Australians. I find, as a non-indigenous Australian, that the motion does not adequately cater for the problems that I have with my mind, my heart, my conscience—and my soul, for that matter—whereas the other wording does.

speech.para: Words can have great meaning. There is great meaning in the word `sorrow' and there is great meaning in the word `regret', and they are two different concepts. I regret if I cannot come around to visit you this afternoon, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I would be very sorry if I injured you in any way, whether in terms of your body or of your mind. The difference between those two words is quite dramatic.

From my point of view, from that of the non-indigenous people with whom I associate, it is clear that the motion as put forward is an effort that needs to be acknowledged. But it certainly does not come to that point which we should now come to, whereas the amendment does. It is for that reason that I am pleased that the opposition has put forward this amendment. It should have been put forward.

I note that Senator Ridgeway says that what he wanted was a unanimous acclamation of the motion. But I do think the situation is such for non-indigenous Australians and, perhaps, for indigenous Australians—he would know that better than I—that perhaps it is already time to say what is said in the amendment. I say that the word `regret' perhaps appeals to the mind; the word `sorry' appeals not only to the mind but to the heart and the soul, and it is the one that should be used in this context.

talk.start.para: —I come to this debate very late. In recent months I have been profoundly affected by a current Senate inquiry into indigenous education. The inquiry has gone to some of the most distant and remote parts of Australia. We have been to Gove, to Bourke, to Brewarrina, to the Torres Strait and to Kintore, which is 400 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs. The week after next we will be going to Kalgoorlie and Laverton. I find myself constantly churning through the issues of what I have seen out in remote and rural Australia, particularly as it relates to the education of Aboriginal people.

speech.para: I was at a private dinner at the ANU last night and, instead of discussing higher ed policy, I found myself discussing for about half an hour what we should do in the area of indigenous education. It has been one of the most difficult policy areas that I have ever come across. What I saw out there really brought home to me the need for us, as an Australian community, to put a massive effort into not only going through this process of reconciliation but trying to do something about the plight of indigenous people in remote areas.

I have come on a long journey in my own attitudes. In 1988 when we had the bicentenary, I got very angry about some of the activities of indigenous people with regard to the bicentenary. I clearly remember my wife and even my children pulling me up on this at that time. But over recent weeks, I have had a profound shift in attitude. The challenge before this parliament is to move the process of reconciliation forward in such a way that we bring the Australian people with us. Changes in attitude will possibly move quite slowly. It is a great pity that in recent years it was set back by the activities of One Nation.

Senator Harris is going to contribute to this debate today. I appeal to you, Senator Harris. I would really like to see the scales fall from your eyes as they have from mine, to see the profound disadvantage that indigenous people suffer because they fall between two cultures. It really behoves us as a parliament to move the process of reconciliation forward and to move forward with practical solutions to improve their lifestyles and help people in these situations achieve their aspirations.

I would like to pay special tribute to Senator Ridgeway for the pivotal role that he has played in recent weeks in moving on this situation and breaking through the impasse that we have had in this area. I think we now have a form of words which the Australian people should be very comfortable with. It is a great pity in this debate that Senator Faulkner did not acknowledge this situation. Obviously, he is pointing to a perfect solution which maybe we will get to in the future. But we have to acknowledge that as a parliament we really have to bring the Australian people with us. I hope that the comments of Senator Ridgeway yesterday, which were widely publicised across the nation, will help bring on a great change of attitude in the Australian people.

Senator Faulkner tended to denigrate the way this statement is worded. Some of the key ideas in this statement included a wholehearted commitment to the cause of reconciliation, an acknowledgment of the mistreatment of many Aboriginal people, reference to a most significant blemish on our national history, and a deep and sincere regret of the injustices indigenous people have suffered in this country. It is a major step forward. Various people in this parliament over the last few years have personally got up and apologised for the treatment of indigenous people. I would like to do that now and put my personal apology and say sorry to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for their mistreatment over the last 200 years.

One of the key areas under discussion in relation to an apology for mistreatment has been the stolen generation. My wife Pam works in the area of social welfare and deals in situations where children have to be removed from their family because they are being mistreated. In the past it was done often with the best of intentions. But the real thing to look at in indigenous situations is whether the children were mistreated and whether or not they were loved in that situation. Errors were obviously made. A lot of those people like Dr O'Donoghue have gone on to great things in our society because they had a more traditional Western education. But we have also got to look at it from the point of view of the parents. I am a father of six. How would I feel? I try to put myself in that situation—if someone turned up to my door and took my six children away. It is that side of what happened that we do have to be profoundly sorry for.

I am heartened that this debate has moved on significantly in the last week. It gives me hope that we can now move on not only to reconciliation but also to a situation where we have a real determination in this country to try and set things right as far as possible and help people who have fallen between two cultures to achieve their aspirations.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion. It is an historic occasion and we should seize the moment now and adopt this motion unanimously. I do not know what the fuss is all about between the words of Senator Faulkner virtually saying, `You have to say sorry,' and the words of the motion `deep and sincere regret.' If you have a look at the dictionary definition of regret, it says `to feel sorry about anything', `to think with a sense of loss.' Surely, we should think about the sense of loss that has been occasioned to everybody in Australia as a result of the injustices perpetrated against the indigenous people of Australia.

speech.para: The dictionary goes on to describe regret as `the feeling of being sorry for some fault, omission, of one's own'—that is, you own it and express regret—`a feeling of sorrow over what is lost, gone, done' and `a polite and formal expression of regretful feelings'. It is a humble expression. When a child does something wrong and the parent says, `Say sorry!', the kid says sorry but may not mean it, whereas `deep and sincere regret' means it.

Senator Bolkus says that Senator Aden Ridgeway has changed his mind since last night. Senator Ridgeway did mention the Queensland motion, but he was clearly referring to other parts of the Queensland statement which are nowhere near as open, fulsome and wholehearted as this particular motion. But there is not time to go into that.

Senator Aden Ridgeway explained the fear that might be engendered. We have to understand that there is a fear and apprehension in the community as to where we are going. I believe our Aboriginal geographical parents at least know that if, on their behalf, we are saying to other Australians, `You have to say sorry,' in that sort of petulant terminology, that does not move us any distance along the way of true reconciliation. I think now we should, as I said, seize the moment and move along the path of true reconciliation and adopt unanimously this motion which is before both houses of parliament.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to this motion and to preface an amendment that I will move later on. The amendment does not detract from the motion; I feel it adds to the sincerity of the motion. Reconciliation is an exchange between more than one party, so it is very obvious that if there is only one party, with whom does that party reconcile?

speech.para: Reconciliation is an issue that faces all Australians. In 1967 a referendum gave the indigenous people of this land the right to vote. That was the time when reconciliation should have started, and it should have been completed well before now. It is an indictment on each Australian—every one of us—that this has not happened. We need to learn from the past and we need to move forward.

There is a bond. Where I come from in North Queensland we live side by side with Aboriginal people. There is a bond, and we need to move on now and build on that bond. I would like to commend the Prime Minister and Senator Ridgeway. I also commend Senator Herron for the marvellous work that he has been doing in the communities, assisting indigenous people in the areas of health, welfare and sanitation. These are the areas that we need to progress. Thank you.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware of any threats to the employment of over 200,000 young Australians? talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Mason very much for that question, because it really goes right to the heart of whether you are seriously committed to improving the economic lot of ordinary Australians. There are something like 400,000 young people under the age of 21, so youth wages is a vitally important issue. What we have managed to do, I think, is to make it very clear where we stand on this issue. We want to not only protect junior rates but now we will permanently exempt traineeships and apprenticeships from age discrimination and require the AIRC, when simplifying awards that apply to work that is or could be performed by young people, to ensure that they support youth employment by including junior rates of pay where appropriate.

answer.para: The Labor Party, very grudgingly, finally came on board—temporarily, I might say—having studied those opinion polls very closely and having realised that the public overwhelmingly support this proposition. I note what Tim Colebatch had to say this morning. He does not always agree with our economics, but he said this:
The economic case for junior wages is overwhelming. Young workers are not born with job-specific skills and experience. . . . The coalition and Labor have done Australia's young workers a favor.

Of course, there are other similar editorials which make it plain that this is the right decision. So really what we should be doing is ensuring that there is no backsliding. But what did Mr Crean have to say this morning? He assured the unions that they did not have to worry because this was all just temporary. He said:
Well, these things will heal. I mean, the relationship between the trade union movement and the Labor Party is a deeply embedded one.

We know what that means. It is a euphemism for, `We will put our people into parliament when we have had enough of them, and in return we will make sure that you get massive handouts,' like the $100 million they got between 1983 and 1996. Mr Crean went on to say this:

What we've got to do is try and find the position that can actually get the numbers in the parliament and ensure that an agenda that the government was hell-bent on introducing . . . is not carried out.

In other words, Mr Crean is making it abundantly clear that this is just a tactical retreat on the part of the Labor Party and is urging the trade union movement to put the greater interest of the movement to the fore so that they can get Labor re-elected, and then it is business as usual. In other words, they will not then be interested in Australian workers; they will be interested in pursuing political outcomes.

That is a tragic outcome from this decision because it was an historic opportunity for Labor to really start moving away, to show that they were not just locked in. Unfortunately, we have the unions making it quite clear what the agenda is, saying things like, `The reason unions affiliated with the ALP was to have the ability to influence political outcomes in the interests of members.' So no-one is under any doubt where they stand. I very interested to see what Steve Roach of the CFMEU said recently. He said:
I have seen many people over the years I have been involved in the movement who looked upon the union movement as an opportunity to advance their own career.
I think if you look in the Senate today you will see a number of people here who would be struggling to find any significant contribution they have made to the union movement.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of conversation in the chamber and across this chamber is unacceptably high.

When they look around this place and they see what they are getting, no wonder they are bitterly disappointed. talk.start.para: —As the minister representing the minister who represents the Minister for Aged Care, I will be happy to try to get you some more detail other than what is in the brief which I have been provided with already. I do think it is a pity that the more senior members of the opposition have not given a briefing to the newer members on areas of policy on which their party is very vulnerable because of their performance while in government. If ever there was such an area, it is this: nursing homes run down, in a terrible state, with Professor Bob Gregory doing a report commissioned by the Labor government as to what needed to be done. How many billions of dollars of expenditure was it? Something like $6 billion? I forget the exact figure but it was a huge figure that needed spending to restore nursing homes in Australia to an acceptable standard for older Australians: safety, fire and all those areas that most of us would want covered very well if it was a case of either ourselves or our parents being in those nursing homes.

answer.para: So, Senator, I am sorry you have not received an adequate brief on your own party's failures. Alimar was a Melbourne home which closed voluntarily this year after a long history of poor care and financial sanctions imposed by the government—but under Labor. It is very typical of what your party turned a blind eye to for a decade: poor quality care, poor providers operating with impunity. That is not to say that is the majority of operators by any means; the majority of homes do deliver excellent care. But our government, unlike the Labor government, will not tolerate the minority who are poor operators. Older Australians deserve better.

I might say that the industry also deserves a better image. Most of the industry is very concerned to ensure that the image of the industry is improved and they support the measures that the government has introduced. We have introduced a new accreditation system, accountability, recognition of excellence and strong action for poor performers. These reform measures of our government, Senator, have got strong support from industry groups and consumers.

I am also pleased to have support from the Australian Democrats—Senators Allison and Woodley. These Democrats are on the record as having said it is a huge step forward. And it highlights the hypocrisy of the Labor Party, who had 13 years in government, were told what needed doing in chapter and verse, well publicised to the nation—Professor Gregory told them authoritatively what they needed to do. That was in about 1994. They had two to three years—in the latter years of their government when they were falling into this policy-free area—to do something important for the older people in Australia, and they failed.

Senator Evans has also been quoted as criticising the system because there is not yet any direct obligation for providers to use the accommodation charges for capital works. I guess this goes somewhat to the area that the senator wanted to hear some details on. Can I say about Senator Evans's comments: what breathtaking hypocrisy! The very thing that he has called for is in an amendment bill that is before the Senate, a bill that has been blocked by the ALP for months. There is no good reason to block it—it only increases residents' protections and it is strongly supported by consumer groups. So why is the ALP playing politics on this again? It is just blatant obstructionism—no ideas, no policy, whingeing, negative and now hypocrisy with criticism about this matter. It is outrageous. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. In light of the coalition's commitment to maintaining the public integrity of the social security system, could the minister please advise the Senate of the current government initiatives to improve that integrity?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Knowles. It is very visible how interested people on our side of the table are in policy compared with the opposition.
—Oh, turn off the record.

—Senator Ray does not like the record but, Senator Ray, it is the truth as well. I appreciate the fact that on this side of the chamber intelligent questions about policy matters are actually introduced onto the public agenda, because this government has indeed been vigilant in maintaining the integrity of the social security system, while at the same time ensuring an adequate social safety net.

answer.para: I do draw to your attention that, under present arrangements, we have been discovering that pensioners are increasingly disposing of assets by giving away up to $10,000 a year as a strategy to remain qualified for the aged pension. This annual free area amounts to $600 more than the actual value of the single rate aged pension, meaning that some people are giving away a full year's worth of pension in order to maximise their social security benefits. The strange thing is that Labor has supported the practice, despite the practice usually being against the pensioner's own best interests—not to mention the country's interests.

Pensioners and early retirees are not to be blamed. They are being actively advised by financial planners to take this option. Even the CPA manual—with 160 pages on social security—gives tips on how to take this action. Some financial planners are more blatant. There are brochures and leaflets commonly containing tips advising pensioners and retirees on how to maximise social security benefits through gifting arrangements.

When the public purse is being raided to pay for the practice, we owe it to taxpayers to ensure that it is kept within a reasonable limit. The Labor Party sees nothing wrong with the loophole and has already flagged that it will vote to maintain the status quo. When you look at their profligate spending during their time in government, you can understand why they might take that attitude. I call on other senators to support a change to these overly generous rules to curtail this financial planning opportunity. It is irresponsible for senators opposite to promote the practice by advocating that older members of the community divest themselves of their retirement nest egg in order to receive relatively small increases in their rate of pension.

What this government intends to do is to halve the limit from $10,000 per annum to $5,000 per annum that an individual can give away in a year, in order to stop the misuse of the gifting provisions. We think that figure is reasonable and allows pensioners the flexibility to help out a family member with a home deposit or a wedding, et cetera. It has nothing to do with the family silver, as one ALP spokesman has said. It is to do with financial measures. People can continue to give away larger sums than the $5,000 but, if they do so, they need to do it in the knowledge that they are deemed by the department to have earned income on any amount over $5,000 and it will be taken into account in determining the rate of their pension. That is fair, it is reasonable.

We are talking here about non-home owning couples with assets of about $476,000 or home owning couples with assets of about $384,000. The change is fair and equitable. It ensures the social security safety net is there for people who have real need, not for the affluent. How can the ALP possibly endorse that in a social security system? Am I to understand from their objection to this measure that it is their socialist chardonnay mates who are going to be wanting to get the pension?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As Senator O'Brien rightly points out, deregulation of the dairy industry is a very contentious issue and I am aware of concerns in several states about possible differential treatment. The Victorian government believes that the removal of these arrangements will provide for improved international competitiveness and increased investment in the Victorian industry with the aim of repositioning the industry to maintain current growth rates.

answer.para: Deregulation in Victoria will have flow-on effects in other states. In the short term, other states will be forced to reduce their regulated prices or abandon regulation altogether as Victorian product moves into higher priced markets. In the longer term, it is expected that all markets will move into parity with Victoria, with some premiums remaining to reflect transport costs and other local supply advantages.

Clearly, this restructuring or rationalisation of the dairy industry is a very important step forward in terms of ensuring that there are level playing fields and that we do not have artificial boundaries and quota arrangements that advantage people in one area rather than another simply because of the level of protection afforded by individual states. We will continue to pursue the concerns that people have expressed and consider the extent to which there may need to be some further announcements made in respect of the taxation treatment of those matters.
