—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ludwig today, relating to legal costs concerning the dismissal of the Secretary of the Department of Defence (Mr Barratt).

My colleague Senator Ludwig's question went to the issue of the costs of the whole farce that we have been subjected to with the ineptitude of this government. We heard the minister say—and rightly so—that he had to see the costs taxed at this stage. But one knows that this will be at a fair expense to the Commonwealth but at an even greater expense to the Department of Defence. In this case, Minister Moore, who is in disarray himself, has left his department in disarray. It has poor morale, great uncertainty and no leadership. The minister has done very little to inspire people under him within his department. If anything, the minister has destabilised his department rather than engendered any sense of hope that the future will be there for Defence to come through a fairly rigorous program that it is undergoing under the defence reform program.

The Barratt affair—if I can call it that at the outset—was a fairly ridiculous affair that the government entered into. The government should not have gone down this path. Instead, it is faced with the question of taxing costs awarded to Mr Barratt in defence of his fundamental right, the right to remain the Secretary to the Department of Defence.

If one looks at the history of this, one sees how the whole sorry saga unfolds. In the affidavit of Mr Maxwell William Moore-Wilton, sworn 2 August in the case of Barratt versus John Winston Howard, one finds that on 16 February 1999 Mr Max Moore-Wilton notes that he drafted an aide-memoire:
for my own use on the result of my consultations relating to the performance of Secretaries of Departments as a basis for a confidential discussion with the Prime Minister.

It is interesting to note in Mr Max Moore-Wilton's affidavit what he had to say to the Prime Minister about the result of the performance testing of the various secretaries of the departments. In his affidavit he says:

The Minister of Defence has negative views about his Secretary. I have raised the Minister's criticism with Mr Barratt personally and he has advised that he has met with the Minister to discuss his performance.
That is fine. But then he goes on to say:

In view of the fact that the Minister has not been Minister of Defence for a substantial period, I consider that there are not sufficient grounds to recommend to you that action be considered in relation to Mr Barratt but the matter of his performance should be reviewed in a year's time.

That seems quite reasonable, indeed. If the minister did have some disagreement with Mr Barratt, that is natural and understandable. But in his affidavit Mr Moore-Wilton goes clearly to the point, to say that the Minister for Defence had not been there for a substantial period of time and that anything relating to Mr Barratt's performance should be deferred for one year. But the government could not wait. Or was it the government? Who were playing in the background to get rid of Mr Barratt who, on the surface, was doing a good job in a very difficult portfolio, in trying to manage the defence reform program as well as a number of other programs and other issues that were put on his plate by this government?
According to Mr Moore-Wilton's affidavit, the aide-memoire went on to say:

The Prime Minister said: "I want time to consider your whole report. I left with him a copy of my aide memoire which he returned to me on 4 March with the annotation on it that appears on Annexure B. It reads:
"As discussed with Mr Moore-Wilton". In communications between the Prime Minister and myself such an annotation indicates his general agreement with the document.
So there was general agreement with the document that had been supplied by Mr Moore-Wilton. On 19 and 20 March, Mr Moore-Wilton went on tell a number of secretaries of departments at a meeting:
The outcome of the review is that the Prime Minister determined that there would be no changes at the present time, and no minister is seeking the replacement of his current secretary.

So there was vindication for the position of Mr Barratt remaining as the secretary to the department. Yet what we have are enormous costs now being accumulated and disruption to the department as a result of what this government has done.

talk.start.para: —I think it is important for the Senate to remind itself that some of these matters are still to be determined. I think it inappropriate and inopportune for Senator Hogg and others to make some of the comments that they have.

speech.para: Senator Hogg interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Hogg!

—Suffice it to say that, if the Labor Party wants to come into this chamber talking about procedural fairness, it might seek to cast its mind back to when Con Sciacca was a federal minister in the previous Labor government. Because who was the first federal parliamentarian to be stung with an unfair dismissal case? It was a Labor minister, who had voted for the legislation and who had pursued the legislation and said it was good. Who was the first parliamentarian to fall foul of it but a Labor minister from the home state of Senator Hogg. I would suggest to Senator Hogg that, if he wants to undermine Mr Sciacca, he ought to be a bit more subtle about it.

speech.para: Most people can see through this. He undoubtedly knew, in raising this issue, that we on this side would remind the Labor Party of their employment history of personnel whilst they were in government. Let me just remind the Labor Party that, if they want to talk about procedural fairness and other matters of that nature, they may well keep in mind their own record and the record of their previous ministers.

talk.start.para: —This is secretaries to departments, Senator.
—Oh! Somehow it is different if it is not your own personal employee. My goodness, Senator Hogg, you would not want to tell your union mates that.
—Would you like to address the chair, please, Senator Abetz.

—Madam Deputy President, I would be delighted to address the chair on this matter. But, of course, when I am provoked by injections from Senator Hogg, I do stray from time to time from the standing orders. What Senator Hogg has also done in this motion and with the comments that he has made is tip a bucket over a former Labor Minister for Defence, Mr Bill Morrison, who appeared on TV and radio and basically said that it ought to be the right of any minister to dismiss the head of his particular department.

speech.para: So it is quite interesting what this exercise seems to be about. It seems to be about Senator Hogg and some of his Labor colleagues wanting to embarrass some of his colleagues and former colleagues rather than come to what is fundamentally the issue here, and that is: who runs a government; who should run a department? We are elected to do that. The minister is appointed in this particular circumstance to do that, and it is appropriate for the minister to take charge of his department and require certain standards. That was a call that the government made, and the government does not withdraw from that. However, the government will abide by any Federal Court decision that is made—indeed, that has been made. As I understand it, Mr Barrett has been given even extra time to put his response. I believe the government has behaved in a manner which is appropriate.

I simply suggest to Senator Hogg, Senator Ludwig and those who would seek to ask questions about this that it is a bit too early to start asking all these questions. Let us see what the ultimate outcome is. Surely the outcome we would all want for this nation is for Defence to be run in a manner which is appropriate.

talk.start.para: —No-one's running it.

—I know the Labor Party is not running Defence, but I can assure you there is one very competent minister, there is one very competent assistant minister, there is one very competent CDF and others involved in running the department and in running the forces. It is business as usual in relation to matters of defence.

speech.para: The Labor Party do themselves no credit in trying to remind us of the sort of unfair dismissal cases that they themselves faced when they were in government, such as that of Senator Hogg's and Senator Ludwig's colleague from Queensland, Mr Sciacca. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have to say that the Liberal Party is an amazing machine. We were just told a minute ago that there is one competent minister—in fact, there are probably a few more than that. But Senator Abetz is much more adept on his feet than the minister that leads the government. When this question was asked today, in view of the prominence that this issue has had in the media in the last couple of weeks I would have thought there would have been a briefing note there and that Senator Hill would have come in and answered the question. You have to give it to Senator Abetz. Three-quarters of an hour later he is down here with the dirt file open. You have to give it to him. He is right into it. Senator Abetz is one of those great performers in this place. He is straight down here. And what does he want to do? Does he want to take up the issue? Does he want to say that this is costing the taxpayers and probably has already cost the taxpayers a lot of money. Not a word of it. No, Senator Abetz wants to rake through the files and find out if someone has ever been sacked before.

speech.para: I have to say to Senator Abetz and to the Senate that this is a government that is proving to be absolutely incompetent at sacking anyone. I remember last year when the Prime Minister was patting Mr Reith—the minister for employment or whatever he calls himself—on the back, because they had managed to sack 5,000 workers on the wharves in this country. He was patting him on the back, saying what a good job he had done. Unfortunately, he had not done as good a job as he thought he had done. He had not done a good job at all, because in fact the courts found, 10 Federal Court judges to one—and I could make some comment about that one dissenting judgment but I will not—that it was incompetently done. So I would have thought that this government would have at least learnt how to deal with one of its top bureaucrats. Not a bit of it. This government does not learn.

What happened was that Mr Barrett—and I will come to Mr Barrett's sins in the moment—was sacked. He got a phone call from Mr Max Moore-Wilton, better known around here as—and I think even the Minister for Justice from this chamber called him this—Max the axe. He told Mr Barrett that his services were no longer required but that possibly some overseas posting could be found for him, because this fellow was in fact enticed into the service, as I understand it—he was a friend of the Prime Minister, and the Prime Minister had asked him to come into the service. So they wanted him to go out with second or third prize. Mr Barrett, as I understand it, made a few counter offers which were not acceptable. The United States is open now. I do not know whether that is a possibility or not. During this week, we have found out that the United States will be available early next year. It may well be that that could be done.

But I must say that one of the roasted chestnuts that I have tasted in this place was the comment by Minister Hill this afternoon that he did not know how much, if anything at all, all this legal stuff is going to cost. I reckon that a member ought to go down and consult the registry of charities in the state of New South Wales and find out if Mr Bob Ellicott and Mr Tom Hughes—both QCs—are on that register. I somehow or other doubt that. I doubt that they are registered as charities. I also doubt that all the money that is going to be paid to them is going to wind up back in taxation to the government. If it does, it is a rather unique job creation scheme.

talk.start.para: —That is a slur on their characters.

—You will get your turn, Senator, in a moment. At the end of the day, both of those QCs are doing their job and doing it for a fee. I have no argument with that, Senator. They have done a good job, a competent job and an excellent job for Mr Barratt. If you want to say anything other than that, I will not say it. But they are not going to be doing this for nothing—and neither should they. Indeed, what we were told here today—
—What about paying their taxes?
—I do not know about their tax arrangements; I have no idea, Senator. (Time expired)

—I want to respond particularly to my friend Senator Quirke and, of course, to Senator Hogg on the issue before us this afternoon. Senator Quirke seems to be preoccupied with how much the legal costs are going to be to the government and the taxpay er with respect to defending the action by Mr Barratt. Whatever the federal High Court decision is—or whatever even more superior courts' decisions are—those costs will be met along the lines of what the courts direct. The government intends to abide by every aspect of the court decisions.

speech.para: I look at what is perhaps part of the problem associated with Mr Barratt—and I am only speculating here, I hasten to say. When I look at costs—when my friend Senator Quirke speaks about legal costs—they are an infinitesimal part of those costs associated with the submarine project, the project designed to bring the then Labor state of South Australia out of its doldrums. We have a rule in this place and in the other place that we do not generally talk about governments' ineptitude with respect to our defence. But just in a generic way I must say that the submarine project is going to prove to be—made so by the former Labor government and by the now Leader of the Opposition in the other place—one of the costliest defence projects in the world, in terms of what we will get.

I do not think the opposition has any right, moral or otherwise, to criticise this government for doing what it can to ensure that the people of Australia have a properly functioning defence department. If the Secretary of Defence was deemed in the proper manner not to be suitable, under the guidelines he had to go.

Let me say that my friend Senator Quirke also said that he thought there would be a briefing note in here today. We did not know what every question was going to be but we just happened to have a briefing note. That procedure with respect to the dismissal of Mr Barratt was followed meticulously. It was followed as for a complex appointment. It is not a simple appointment of `Come in, have a look, see if you like it; and we will sign you on.' It is not that, and you on the other side know that it is not that.

You know that a departmental secretary is appointed by the Governor-General for a fixed term of up to five years and that the Prime Minister and the Public Service Commissioner determine those terms and conditions of appointment under the Public Service Act of 1922. The Remuneration Tribunal determines the salary and allowances under the Remuneration Tribunal Act of 1973. That was followed meticulously. The Governor-General, however, may direct that an appointment be terminated following advice from the Prime Minister. That was followed meticulously, based upon a report to the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet—or, in this case, with Mr Barratt—following a report from the Public Service Commissioner. All of that was followed meticulously.

There is no suggestion in your argument this afternoon that that was not done. There is no suggestion that, with respect to severance pay, that was wrong. The tribunal has a long-standing and applicable determination that provides compensation when a fixed term appointment is prematurely terminated.

talk.start.para: —Tell us why.

—The termination provides, Senator, for one-third of a month's salary for each full month of the balance of the fixed term not served, and it is subject to a maximum payment of 12 months salary. Were the determination to be applied to Mr Barratt's circumstances, it would result in a payout of one year's base salary—that is, $250,000—as he has served less than two years of his term, because he was appointed, as I recall, on 31 December 1997.

speech.para: There is no suggestion that that was not followed meticulously. I think that, just like you have with the Federation Fund and like you have with your silly questions this afternoon, trying to draw out 16 allocations of funds that were for the betterment of Australia, you have drawn here a loser again. You are losing again. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government is still trying to sack Barratt after some five weeks.
—`Mr' Barratt—
—Mr Barratt, if you prefer; but from the way that you have been treating him—

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—
Senator Lightfoot interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—It is a matter that started when you put him on in February 1998 for five years. At the rate that you are going in trying to get rid of him, it will be another five years. If we look at what you are trying to do, you are trying dismiss him. There are procedures that you could follow. Senator Lightfoot has alluded to procedures that were followed, but the court apparently does not agree. The court found that Mr Barratt was entitled to procedural fairness. The government, on the other hand, argued—and they argued, I suspect, with all the legal finesse they were able to muster—that they could sack him at their pleasure.
—No. That was never it.

—We can take you to the briefing note. I am happy to provide that. It seems that the approach that this government wish to take in respect of dismissals is that they want to be able to dismiss people at their pleasure. A departmental head or a hard-working public servant might also fall under that. But we still find them today bungling that attempt. They have not even managed to do it. The courts have upheld fairness and justice. It does not, in our view, augur well for the effective administration of the Department of Defence. No doubt the minister is finding it difficult to find a replacement. With the record that he has got around his neck, you would expect that there would not be too many starters, unless they have got a bullet-proof vest on.

speech.para: This silly fiasco, which has gone on for quite some time, needs to come to a conclusion. Mr Barratt in his previous job was head of the Business Council in Melbourne, and he was recruited to the Public Service at a much later date. Now he might be able to turn his mind to supporting Labor in ensuring fairness from the Industrial Relations Commission with respect to dismissals so that justice can prevail. Not only did you argue that you could dismiss him at your pleasure but also, when the court did not agree with you, you tried to say that the costs do not follow the event, that Mr Barratt is not entitled to costs. You tried to argue that he should mind his own costs and that you would look after yours. At a time when the defence department needs careful and considered decision making, needs certainty and needs good information in its hands, there is no-one in the top job. This continuing squabbling is not providing any certainty for Defence.
What is even more surprising is that Mr Barratt got a pay rise in March of the order of $40,000, as reported in the Sun-Herald of 1 August 1999. Things must have slid downhill pretty quickly—

talk.start.para: —You are wrong.

—You can go to the Sun-Herald of 1 August 1999 and read it for yourself. Mr Barratt had indicated in July his view that everything was going well. There must have been a very fine line between things going very well and things going very badly. What is appalling, in truth, when you stand back and look at this sorry mess, is that the important issues are not being concentrated on, important issues on which the minister has abrogated his responsibilities. No-one is at the helm of the ship and there is plenty of work that needs to be done, like replacing destroyers and fixing the F111s. (Time expired)

—Many honourable senators who have participated over recent years in inquiries into the Department of Defence or aspects involving the Department of Defence would no doubt have been, like me, very concerned that they did not perhaps get the direct answers that they were looking for. Answers have often been evasive, obscure, irrelevant, voluminous and not to the point. So it is not surprising that the minister has obviously found certain difficulty with his CEO. We acknowledge that Mr Barratt has been recruited from the private sector. Defence is such an important department of state that we had to have a man from a civilian point of view oversighting that and administering it who can get on top of the issues and run the department successfully in the best interests of this country. Quite obviously problems arose because the performance was not up to Minister Moore's high standards. We were not getting the improvements, we were not getting the responses and we were not getting the action that was required, and under the circumstances termination is the only way out.

speech.para: Questions have arisen as to procedural fairness. This particular gentleman is paid an exceedingly high amount of money. In that package are built-in arrangements for extra payment for issues such as—

talk.start.para: —Performance.

—I will take that comment, because that report on performance pay is not correct. He did not receive that amount, and I think that should be put to rest. Under the Public Service Act, a secretary's appointment can be terminated at any time by the Governor-General on advice from the Prime Minister following a report from the secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. He knew that when he signed the contract and he was amply rewarded. That was a risk he took. There are a lot of CEOs who sign similar arrangements, because these fixed term contracts are very common not only in the public sector but in the private sector nowadays.

speech.para: I point out to the opposition that successive governments have understood the legal position to be that natural justice does not apply to such determinations. Prima facie, you may say that that is quite unfair, but, in recognition of such limited tenure and similar issues, secretaries receive a 20 per cent loading, which is now rolled into their base pay. It is quite generous and is something that you and I do not get. There is also an entitlement to a lump sum termination equivalent to one-third of the unexpired period of their term of employment up to a maximum of 12 months pay.

For the benefit of honourable senators, I point out that these secretaries are currently employed for terms of up to five years. This is one of a number of fundamental changes to tenure arrangements for secretaries which were made by the previous government, your government, in the years 1984 to 1994. The previous government has also removed secretaries as and when that government chose. The departures of Mr Ron Brown and Mr Graham Evans were quite controversial, as was the resignation of Mr Mike Codd, a great secretary who did much to reform the public sector when secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, when Mr Keating succeeded Mr Hawke. I think that is noteworthy.

As I have so few minutes left, I think I should state that the government intends to fully abide by the decision of the Federal Court. The government itself has not made its decision. The secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has actually written to Mr Barratt outlining the reasons for his dismissal. The Secretary to Prime Minister and Cabinet still awaits, I understand, Mr Barratt's response. I have every confidence that Mr Barratt will be extended complete fairness in the terms of the contract, which is not dissimilar to the contracts which you arranged. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The bill puts in place arrangements to fulfil the agreement reached at the 1999 Premiers' Confer ence on the level and distribution of general revenue assistance to the States and Territories in 1999-2000. The bill also provides authority for the Commonwealth to pay to the States and Territories the revenue it will collect in 1999-2000 under the safety net arrangements which were implemented to protect State and Territory revenues following the 1997 High Court decision, which severely curtailed the States' capacity to raise revenues through business franchise fees.

The bill will amend the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. The existing act covers the provision of financial assistance for 1998-99, with interim arrangements for the continuation of payments for a maximum of six months. The bill extends for a further 12 months the provisions of the act relating to the payment of financial assistance grants and State and Territory entitlements to payments under the safety net arrangements.

The general revenue assistance to be appropriated by this bill is about $17.7 billion or around 11.3 per cent of estimated Commonwealth expenses in 1999-2000. Accordingly, these payments constitute a significant element of the Commonwealth Budget and have an important bearing on the spending and borrowing of the public sector as a whole. The States and Territories are able to allocate the funds provided by the Commonwealth under this act according to their own budgetary priorities.

In addition, revenue replacement payments to the States under the safety net arrangements are estimated to be $6.8 billion in 1999-2000. The safety net arrangements are revenue neutral for the Commonwealth.
I turn now to the elements of the bill which give effect to the Commonwealth's funding commitments to the States and Territories.

The major part of the assistance provided under this bill is the payment to each State and Territory of a share of the pool of financial assistance grants, which is estimated to be about $17.3 billion in 1999-2000. The distribution of financial assistance grants will be in accordance with the five-year per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The bill updates the per capita relativities accordingly.

The States and Territories will be provided with real per capita growth in financial assistance grants in 1999-2000. The per capita element of the real per capita guarantee is conditional on States meeting the terms of the Agreement to Implement the National Competition Policy and Related Reforms. This Agreement also provides for up to $439.1 million in competition payments to the States and Territories in 1999-2000. The views of the National Competition Council will be taken into consideration by the Commonwealth in deciding whether a State or Territory should receive the payments provided under the National Competition Policy Agreement in 1999-2000.

The Australian Capital Territory will also receive $13.2 million from the Commonwealth in 1999-2000 in the form of transitional allowances and special fiscal needs. This payment is outside the scope of this bill and has been included in the Appropriation Bills for the 1999-2000 Budget.
I turn now to the elements of the bill which relate to the safety net arrangements.

The safety net measures introduced by the Commonwealth protect State and Territory revenues following the High Court's 5 August 1997 decision on State business franchise fees. The Commonwealth is using its tax powers to collect the revenue that the States and Territories previously collected by way of business franchise fees on petroleum products, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. The States and Territories acknowledge that this represents a State tax imposed and collected by the Commonwealth at their unanimous request and on their behalf.

The proposed amendments provide authority for the Commonwealth to pay the States and Territories the revenue it collects under the safety net arrangements in 1999-2000. These payments are estimated to be $6.8 billion in 1999-2000. A new `per stick' excise regime for tobacco will be introduced from 1 November 1999. However, State safety net shares of tobacco excise will continue to be calculated on the existing excise arrangements. Accordingly, the bill includes a further amendment to the act, so that any variation in the method of calculating duty on petroleum, tobacco and alcohol products will leave the States' entitlement to customs or excise duty, under the safety net arrangements, the same as that due prior to the amendment.

The bill also include provisions which return to the States and Territories any tax revenues the Commonwealth might receive under the Franchise Fees Windfall Tax (Collection) Act 1997. This will ensure that State and Territory finances are protected from claims for refunds, on grounds of constitutional invalidity, of past payments of business franchise fees.

As noted earlier, the safety net arrangements are revenue neutral for the Commonwealth. Revenue replacement payments will simply return to the States and Territories amounts raised by the Commonwealth on their behalf, after allowing for Commonwealth administrative costs.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—

(a) recognises the unique and harsh conditions under which Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel work and the fact that the ADF is not an ordinary workforce and has never been treated that way by previous governments;
(b) notes that:
(i) as a result of the new fringe benefits tax (FBT) reporting regime, put in place as part of the Government's new tax system, extreme hardship will be experienced by ADF personnel, and
(ii) the Government has decided to exempt only a few of the fringe benefits and allowances that ADF personnel receive from the new FBT reporting regime; and

(c) calls on the Government to continue to recognise the unique status of the ADF and to therefore exempt all ADF personnel from the FBT reporting requirements in respect of the conditions and benefits they receive because of their service in the armed forces.

This motion relates to Australian Defence Force personnel and, in particular, the current situation regarding the fringe benefits tax regime as a result of the ANTS package. I have moved this motion because I come from an electorate in which we have a large number of Defence Force personnel—in Darwin and at Tindal. This issue has been raised with me over the last couple of weeks by these people, who believe that this is an issue of actual crisis currently happening within the Defence Force. Some people may or may not be aware that there was a shift many years ago to make Darwin the focal point of Defence Force activities in this country, and certainly Tindal, which is situated just out of Katherine, is the main air take-off base for this country.

This issue is before the Senate because it comes as a result of the government's ANTS package, which of course has now been passed and which led to changes in the fringe benefits tax. This means that from July 2000 group certificates will include the grossed up value of fringe benefits received by employees. These will be reported on their annual group certificates. The value of fringe benefits will now be used for any means testing of social security payments and taxation surcharges. It will also be taken into account in determining liability for child support payments.

Members of this chamber may well recall that, when this was first introduced some months back, I stood up and successfully moved an amendment to exempt people from the Northern Territory who were living in remote conditions. At the time we argued that this would have repercussions on the numbers and kinds of people that would be attracted to work in remote areas, by virtue of the fact that allowances and conditions that were attached to their jobs were there because of their remoteness and their locality, as opposed to a desire by these people to obtain these conditions and allowances in any kind of salary packaging. In fact, it is all part of their conditions of service and, in a way, it is an enticement or a recruitment mechanism to actually get people into rural and remote Australia.

The government recognised that argument and supported our amendment in relation to exempting those people from the FBT arrangements. But the effect on Defence Force personnel of what we have currently before us in relation to the fringe benefits reporting act will be serious and harsh repercussions for these workers. They were not considered when the original bill was drafted and I think the impact that the new legislation will have on the Defence Force personnel is an unintended consequence.

Following the passage of the new tax legislation through parliament, and similar amendments to the child support legislation last year, the Australian Taxation Office, under advice from Treasury, made a ruling that Australian Defence Force personnel were to be treated like any other employees and brought within the new arrangements. This will mean that the ADF's unique remuneration system, which is disproportionately distorted by fringe benefits and allowances, will be subject now to the fringe benefits group certificate reporting regime. As a result, the value of fringe benefits will be taken into account, as I said, for social security means test purposes and child support assessment, and for the taxation surcharges which will be levied on the combined taxable income and reportable fringe benefits. The practical outcome is a significant drop in, and in many cases a halving of, the disposable income of about 10 per cent of ADF personnel.

But this decision now taken by Treasury is inconsistent with a 1996 Industrial Relations Court ruling. That ruling identified ADF personnel not as a work force in this country that has a normal employee-employer relationship but as a separate and special category of employees, exposed to significantly different and harsh working conditions. In fact, the situation with their employment conditions and recognition is also carried through to their normal determination of wages and conditions through the Remuneration Tribunal, as opposed to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

It also goes against the tradition of previous Labor governments, which treated ADF personnel remuneration with special consideration. I think it is fair to say that, until this government included Defence Force personnel within the scope of the Fringe Benefits Reporting Act, all governments had recognised the distinct and unique nature that Defence Force personnel bring to this country when they put up their hand to serve their country. They are not normal employees; they are in fact servants of the Crown and are subject to a separate and special category of conditions.

The rationale in the past, I think, for ADF having special consideration has always been that they are exposed to severe hardships and extreme restrictions compared with other groups of workers in this country. Comparably, their remuneration is fairly poor. They have no access to normal industrial rights. They are prevented from industrial representation and from being union members. There is of course the Armed Forces Federation, which has a very small number of members by comparison with all of the work force, but it is not categorised as a trade union and it does not take its members' concerns before an industrial tribunal or the Arbitration Commission.

Strike action by Defence Force personnel is illegal. They have a separate and severely strict justice system. There are compulsory postings. They are on-call 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and there is no overtime paid for extra duties. And, last but not least, they are the men and women who are sent to defend this country, who are sent into combat to protect Australia.

The fringe benefits, most of which were established under the Labor government, include subsidised housing, free air travel on scheduled RAAF aircraft flights if seating is available and home-garaging of ADF vehicles if a member is on-call. I want to take senators through some of the implications this has on a personal level and then through a summary of what I think has been quite a fiasco in the handling of this Fringe Benefits Tax Reporting Scheme by Minister Moore since 10 August.

We have had—and when I say `We' I also talk about the member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon—considerable representation from members in the Northern Territory and from Defence Force people in the Northern Territory. I took it upon myself last week to travel to Katherine to meet people at Tindal. They handed me a letter, and I want to quote from it because I think it is important to get a feel for how I think Defence Force people are feeling about this, the urgency which they want this dealt with and, I suppose, the sincerity with which they want the government to treat it. The letter from this person at Tindal says:

Postings to the Tindal location have always been difficult to fulfil. This is my second tour and without these traditional entitlements many members and myself posted here would opt for a discharge instead of placing their family or themselves in a financial disadvantage.
A particular benefit that comes under this regime in relation to the Northern Territory is the remote locality travel leave. This:

Is an annual free travel entitlement based on family structure offset to the nearest capital city ie. Adelaide. Such entitlement exists because Darwin still cannot provide adequate hospital facilities enjoyed by eastern coast cities.

They also enjoy an airconditioning allowance, and if you have ever gone anywhere near Katherine and Tindal in what we call `the wet season', you would enjoy nothing more after two weeks out in the bush than to come back to an airconditioned house. The letter states:

A small proportion of Defence Establishments falls under this umbrella. However, Tindal as the frontline Airpower location will not receive any exemption to omit this allowance as an assessed FBT allowance.
Regarding the Defence Housing Subsidy:
Service personnel whom are married or maintain dependants are entitled to married quarters. These MQ's are administered by DHA—
the Defence Housing Authority—
and members pay approx. 48% of the market rate, with Defence remunerating the remainder.

There has been quite a deal of pressure put on this government by the Department of Defence. I have before me a submission by the Department of Defence to Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office, relating to the fringe benefits tax issues. Let me quote some of the aspects of the executive summary, where even the Department of Defence do not agree with the actions of this government and the way in which they have treated our Defence Force personnel. The summary says:

We, the Department of Defence, seek exemption from the FBT group certificate reporting requirements for specific conditions of service paid to our staff solely due to the nature of Defence employment.

Here we have the Department of Defence, in a submission to Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office, seeking an exemption from this fringe benefits tax reporting requirement and recognising and stressing to this government that the group certificate reporting requirements are solely due to the nature of Defence employment. They go on to say:
Further, we request that these conditions of service be reviewed by you to confirm whether they should be subject to FBT at all.
The submission goes on to say:
Defence does not take lightly this request for exemption from the FBT group certificate reporting requirements for specific conditions of service.
There is an admission by the defence department that this is not easy, that they are not treating this flippantly. They state that they do not take this request lightly. They go on to say:

This Submission focuses only on those conditions that are affected by regional impacts, and the Australian Government's requirement that we maintain a presence in a wide range of locations throughout Australia in order to prevent or defeat the use of armed force against Australia or its National interests.
It goes on to say:
We request our concerns be addressed by a reporting exemption in a specific regulation, as allowed for in the Act.

There are many examples throughout the submission where the Department of Defence tries to impress upon the Taxation Office and Treasury the uniqueness of the conditions under which Defence Force personnel put their hand up and say they will serve this country and what they expect in return for this. The submission goes on to say:

The conditions of service for which Defence seeks group certificate reporting exemption are longstanding provisions associated with the special nature of Defence service, which differs substantially from those in the general community or other public sector employment.

In some cases, the conditions of service were determined long before the introduction of the FBT, they are not available to other members of the ADF or civilian defence employees and they are not part of any salary sacrifice arrangements. They go on to say:
We reiterate the conditions of service are a direct consequence of Defence's operational requirements.

I do not think you can get it clearer than that. You cannot get it more plainly than that. In black and white, the Department of Defence has stressed upon the government that these are people who are not subject to the same employee conditions as anyone else. They are a particular and unique category of our citizenship who put their hands up to defend this country at any time of the day, any week of the year. For that they will now be penalised through the introduction of this fringe benefits tax reporting regime.

There is an example that is close to my own electorate. This submission talks about a whole range of allowances, including housing assistance, airconditioning assistance, discharge removals, discharge travel, the removal of non-service spouse on the breakdown of a marriage, removals in the same locality, child-care reimbursement allowance, compassionate leave travel, remote locality leave travel, reunion travel, and the Defence Service Home Loan Scheme. The list goes on and on. In relation to the Defence housing, the submission says:
. . . it should be noted that some Defence "remote" areas, and thus high cost areas—
such as Katherine and Darwin—
are not considered remote for FBT purposes and, therefore, have no concessional valuation treatment. The most obvious example is in Darwin.
What have we got as a response from this government? I suppose the question could be asked of Minister Moore: what is he good for?

talk.start.para: —He is good for destroying the defence department.

—That is exactly right, Senator Faulkner. When this issue was raised in the House of Representatives on 10 August, his response was that this government would review the situation. That is all. He said, `We will take it on board and we will review the situation.' In the meantime, there are Defence Force personnel around this country who are questioning why they opt to take on this career and why they seek to relocate their families to places such as Darwin, Katherine and remote areas of this country. There are people who are questioning what they are prepared, for our sakes, to give up in the line of duty.

speech.para: Minister Moore said he was going to review the situation. What did we find after he had reviewed the situation? That he had decided to exempt housing. He decided that one thing could be dropped off the list, and that was the housing allowance. On 11 August he made an announcement that the housing allowance will essentially be exempted from fringe benefits tax reporting provisions. My response to Ministers Moore and Scott is that their decision to exempt only housing assistance from the fringe benefits reporting regime is a half-baked response. It is almost as though it had been flippantly put on the list of the many things these people are entitled to. It was as though the minister said, `The first one off the list will be housing, but I am not too worried about the rest of them.' We say that this is not good enough. We are calling for all of these conditions to be exempt.

I believe that the government has been half-hearted in protecting the Australian Defence Force personnel and their conditions of service. The Defence Personnel Chief Executive's instructions list more than 45 allowances and benefits, other than the housing assistance, which will be treated as gross income for the fringe benefits tax reporting requirements.

In question time some weeks ago in the House of Representatives, Minister Scott cited the example of a general not having the fringe benefits tax on his personal car treated as income for the new fringe benefits tax reporting requirements. But that just ignores the fact that the vast majority of the allowances are, in places, to compensate service personnel for the unique circumstance of service life. It might come as a surprise that the majority of the people in the Defence Force are not generals and they are not given cars for private use.

This government does not want to understand the personnel in the Defence Force, is not prepared to recognise the uniqueness of the conditions under which they work and is not prepared to recognise the difficulties that many of these families now go through and put up with, and the sacrifices they make, to defend this country. We now have a government that not only mismanages the Defence Force—by virtue of the saga we have had over the recent sacking of its leader and chief—but also is prepared to turn its back on Defence Force personnel and not treat them with the distinction and the uniqueness that they deserve when they put their hands up to defend this country.

talk.start.para: —It is a delight to lead on behalf of the government on this motion put before us by Senator Crossin and the Labor Party. I congratulate Senator Crossin for involving herself and taking an interest in matters related to the Defence portfolio. But I invite her to first acquaint herself with the facts before she seeks to involve herself in debates of this nature.

speech.para: The motion that is before us is in fact a slap-dash motion with two separate errors in it. Paragraph 1 has the word `the' missing and paragraph 2 has an extra `that' in it. As a result, it does not in fact even read correctly. But I have to say that it is, unfortunately, not only a punctuation problem with this motion; the really serious defect is the lack of substance in it. The Liberal and National parties have a very proud record of looking after Defence generally and, in particular, the personnel. In fixing the devastated economy that we inherited in 1996, we dealt with a lot of budget matters—

talk.start.para: —Paul Barratt?
—`Pork-barrelling' says the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, who is not even sitting in his correct seat.
—I said `Paul Barratt'.

—We quarantined Defence from any federal government cuts. The Labor Party—in particular, the left wing—were strongly opposed to the quarantining of Defence, yet here they are trying to suggest that they are the champions of Defence. The reality is that, whenever they have been in government, they have treated Defence with a degree of sufferance on the basis of, `Yeah, we have to put up with it; we can't get rid of it, and we will give them as little funding as we can get away with.' The personnel within Defence know quite well how supportive we are of Defence personnel generally and in relation to the Defence portfolio.
—You've presided over the greatest crisis in morale in the history of the ADF.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate continually interjecting out of his seat. I would ask you to invite him to abide by the two standing orders that he is breaching: one, by interjecting; two, by doing so from not within his seat.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, it is disorderly to interject when not in your seat. If you wish to interject—
—I'll return to my seat and interject from there.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, you were in fact invited in my point of order to also remind the honourable senator that it is disorderly to interject. I would ask that, if it should become necessary in the future, you might remind him of that also.
—Senator, thank you for those comments. I will note them.
—Good.
—But I would also remind you that, if you do wish to refer to a point of order, it is useful to preamble your comments under that heading.
—Fool!
—Madam Acting Deputy President, you are not going to let that go, are you?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order: seeing as you refuse to request your leader to withdraw—

speech.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You know, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it is disorderly to refer to a fellow senator as a `fool', and I would invite you to ask the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to withdraw the comment.
—Senator Faulkner, it is unparliamentary—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether it is or not, but I certainly withdraw it. I take a point of order: I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Boswell has been continuously interjecting. He has moved in and has tried to muscle in on someone else's seat. I don't know whose it is.
—He looks very good on the front bench.
—He would. He seems to fit in quite well.
—No, you can't; I'm taking a point of order.
—I am supposed to be in that seat that he is speaking from. Unless I sit on his knee, I cannot be in the right seat.
—Bos, you have my permission. Why don't you sit on his knee? You can't interject from that seat.
—Have you finished your point of order, Senator Faulkner?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, my point of order is a serious one. I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Boswell is being disorderly. He may well have been provoked by Senator Abetz, who seems to be wasting a lot of time in his own contribution—but given he has nothing to say about the matter it is hardly surprising. I would ask you to be vigilant about Senator Boswell who is, I think, testing the patience of every senator in the chamber.
—The standing orders apply equally to both sides of this chamber. I have already reminded senators that it is not orderly to interject from outside of their ordinary seats.

—I will return to the substance—and that is using the term very loosely indeed—and deal with the four paragraphs. It is correct to say that ADF personnel do work under unique and, indeed, difficult conditions. In fact, we have continually recognised that. The ADF personnel have been treated by this government and previous governments of all persuasions in a special way because of the special service that they render to our country. Whilst it may be difficult for some people to realise or understand those special circumstances in times of peace, the reality is that they are our front line of defence and they have made a vow—in fact, taken an oath—to put their lives on the line to defend our country. As a result, they are special people within our community. They deserve special recognition for that, and governments need to be mindful of the difficult circumstances under which they operate.

speech.para: Indeed, it is very disruptive to family life not only within their own family but also within the broader family community of ADF members. It really is a very difficult life. In this place, Madam Acting Deputy President, we often think that our throats are cut because we are away from our family so often, but those who serve, especially in the Navy and in other areas of the forces, have to put up with even greater absences from their families than we do.

That was brought home to me just recently when I made a number of visits, such as visits to Endeavour Cottage at Latham Park naval complex near Kingsford Smith, to RAAF Williamtown and, in my own home state of Tasmania, to Dowsings Point, where I had the opportunity of speaking with spouses of Defence personnel. The message came through loud and clear—not from the Labor Party opposition but from the personnel themselves—that they had certain difficulties with the implementation of aspects of our fringe benefits tax. As a government we took that on board and have made, I believe, the appropriate adjustments that they were wanting to have made.

Senator Crossin made the direct link between our tax policies and the way that that would have applied to Defence personnel. With respect to Senator Crossin, let me direct her attention to what the Labor Party policy was at the last election in relation to fringe benefits tax. For Defence personnel, it was absolutely identical to the one we took to the election. So do not let them come here and suggest that somehow they know about the difficulties that this particular policy might mean for Defence personnel. Indeed, it was the Labor Party that refused to exempt Defence as an organisation from the fringe benefits tax when they introduced the legislation in 1986. They went to the October 1998 election with the same widening of the fringe benefits reporting legislation that they now claim they are opposed to.

They voted for the fringe benefits tax legislation which they now say they oppose. They moved no amendments when this legislation was before the parliament, and at no time did they state any intention to exempt ADF personnel. Indeed, the Labor Party on this issue remind me of that American adven turer, Robert Bogucki. They are lost in a policy wilderness not really knowing where they are going or what they are doing but hoping that somehow, if they wander along far enough, they might stumble across something. As Robert Bogucki was found by a muddy waterhole trying to sustain himself, so the Labor Party have been found at a pretty dry, muddy watering hole in relation to policy. (Quorum formed)

It is most flattering that Senator Faulkner should invite so many other senators into the chamber to listen to what is a very good contribution on behalf of the government. I can see no other reason that Senator Faulkner would have called the quorum; I am sure it would not have been just to waste the time of the Senate. The simple fact is that the Australian Labor Party went to the last election with exactly the same fringe benefits tax policy in relation to Defence personnel. They voted for that legislation, and now they are seeking to assert somehow that they were never part of it.

The reality is that housing assistance makes up two-thirds of Defence's total fringe benefits tax. So, by getting rid of that, we have basically dealt with the substantial problem. It is a situation in Defence where people are often posted to outlying areas. They have no say in their posting; they have to follow the request that is made and, as a result, I believe it is appropriate that the government has made the decision that it has.

It was interesting to listen to Senator Crossin, because she complained that somehow the new system will impact on people's social security payments and entitlements. As I understand it, reading from page 60, `A fairer tax system with no GST'—which was the Labor Party policy of the last election—we were told:

A Labor government will reform the Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) to . . . include on group certificates the grossed-up value of fringe benefits for income tested surcharges and government benefits where these are in excess of $1,000, and include the non-grossed-up value of a wider range of fringe benefits for—
guess what purpose—
social security purposes . . .
They then said:
these will be included on employees' group certificates by employers . . .

That was Labor Party policy, and in fact they voted for it. It is really, therefore, quite hypocritical for the Labor Party to come in here and try to dissociate themselves from a policy that they themselves had been embracing.

It is interesting to note that Senator Crossin and Mr Martin, the shadow minister for defence, somehow think that it is trivialising the matter whether a General's car being used for private purposes ought to be considered to be a fringe benefit. I invite the Labor Party speakers on this motion to in fact address that. Do they believe that those sorts of benefits should be included on the group certificate because, quite clearly from Mr Martin's press release, he believes that they should? And, if that is the case, how on earth can you have paragraph 4 in your motion which calls on the government to `exempt all ADF personnel from the FBT reporting requirements'? Why should they all be exempted when you in fact acknowledge that some of them should be included?

This is a clear and classic case of Labor's schizophrenia when it comes to policy. They really do not know where they are in relation to these important matters. We say those that should continue to be reported are clearly personal benefits such as private use of Commonwealth cars; cheap home loans; free flights on Defence aircraft—albeit not for personal reasons such as when somebody has died; semi-official phones; HECS payments; recreational free travel; spouse accompanied travel; property; and prizes and gifts. These are not unique to ADF personnel. Many are available to civilian public servants such as education assistants, et cetera, and they will all be reported. In fact many things, such as the free or cheap air flights that Ansett and Qantas staff receive, are now reportable on group certificates. Why should it be different in relation to Defence aircraft? I invite the Australian Labor Party to deal with those issues.

We are trying to ensure a taxpayer's total remuneration is taken into account when assessing an individual's liabilities for payments like child support or surcharges, or when assessing the need for government benefits like family allowance—and this is important. The principle is that those members of our community with the capacity to contribute fairly to our taxation base should do so, and government benefits should be targeted at those in greatest need. Indeed, those words are virtually identical to what you can read in the Labor Party's fringe benefits tax policy that they took to the last election—and they voted for that legislation in this parliament.

We as a government are very proactive in supporting our Defence personnel. We are concerned about them being appropriately looked after. We have been very anxious to make sure that they are looked after, and we have indicated that we are prepared to look at issues when and as they arise and deal with them. There are allowances and benefits that are already exempt or not reportable, such as airconditioning allowance, compassionate travel, home purchase and sales expense allowance for all but first purchase and sale on discharge, most removals, transferee travel and accommodation, entertainment, car parking and use of cars for official purposes. So we are looking after Defence personnel. (Quorum formed)
The good thing is that I can report to the Senate that the Chief of the Defence Force, Admiral Barrie, in a media release dated 20 August 1999, welcomed our decision and made this very telling point:
Like all Australian taxpayers, ADF personnel should have allowances that are consistent with the rest of the community reported on their Group Certificates.

The point to be made is that, if it is something unique in relation to service in the defence forces, it should be exempted, and that is what the government has said, especially in the area of housing. The airconditioning allowance has also been exempted because it is particularly unique to service in the defence forces. But where the defence forces receive allowances and benefits that are not necessarily unique to the defence forces, it is appropriate that those allowances and benefits be reported on their group certificates and that they pay tax accordingly, or indeed—this is an important aspect—that any social security responsibilities or child support responsibilities be undertaken by that individual.

What will happen under Senator Crossin's proposal is that—and this is often the case—the separated women at home with the kids will be denied extra funding through the Child Support Scheme because the blokes in the forces will be able to avoid their child support responsibilities. Some of these benefits are paid to them, in effect, in lieu of a salary, and therefore they can avoid their parental responsibility. I would have thought that Senator Crossin, being a female senator in this place, would have been severely condemnatory of any system that did not give women in particular sufficient funds to assist them in bringing up their children. This motion is not a motion of substance. It has errors in it, both in punctuation and substance. I invite the Senate to reject it.

talk.start.para: —Having just heard Senator Abetz in this debate, I wonder why he wasted our time in demanding that we call his colleagues in to listen to him, because unfortunately, Senator Abetz, I do not think you have some of your facts quite correct.

speech.para: As far as Labor Party policy is concerned, it has never been part of Labor Party policy, as I am informed by the shadow minister, to have any contribution to FBT in terms of Australian Defence Force personnel placed on the group certificate. Apparently, this is a line that is being peddled by Minister Scott to try to cover up the mess that the government has made once again in this important area.

As I understand the position, there are only two items that thus far have been exempted from FBT being shown on the group certificate. Primarily, they are the issues of housing, which Senator Abetz raised, and funerals. Whilst the housing item contributes significantly to the FBT that Defence pays in respect of some of its personnel, there are nonetheless a significant range of other items that are involved which do attract FBT and which, when placed on the group certificate, will place Defence Force personnel at a disadvantage which they have not so far experienced.

It just so happens that in recent times a number of us visited Defence establishments in Queensland—within about the last three weeks. I have been to the Enoggera Army Barracks, the Lavarak Army Barracks in Townsville and the RAAF base in Townsville. Quite interestingly, all the personnel, whether they were in the ranks or were officers, greeted us with the same chord, which was, `Do something about this FBT. It is not something that it is fair to levy upon us.'

I will come to the point that Senator Abetz raised. He tries to make out that these people in the Defence Force should be and can be treated exactly the same as every other person out there in the real world. Of course, their world is quite different. They are committed to a very important task, that task being the defence of this nation, and they are placed under different stresses and different circumstances than many other people in the so-called normal work force.

As part of the visit to the various barracks that I have outlined, I also had the opportunity through the Defence Community Organisation to meet with the spouses of serving personnel in Brisbane and Townsville. And surprise, surprise! What did one find? They were equally miffed by the fact that the group certificates of their spouses would be attracting the amount for FBT. This will disadvantage these people who, in many cases, already consider themselves disadvantaged because of dislocation primarily from family and from the extended family in particular. And in many circumstances they do not enjoy the most gracious of climates, particularly in the hot months in the northern parts of Australia in places such as Townsville and Darwin.

I hope to have another chance to meet with defence personnel in Darwin in the not too distant future. I am sure that they will come up with exactly the same complaint about what the government are doing or what the government have done. They will undoubtedly express their dismay at what the government have done in this particular area. The voice of the defence personnel spouses, whilst not necessarily heard loudly throughout the community, undoubtedly is heard loudly throughout the political processes and is also carried very well through the Defence Community Organisation. The government need to pay attention to this very important group of people, because there needs to be stability for the spouses as well as for serving Defence personnel. They are clearly upset by the application of the FBT to certain benefits that they see making their lifestyle bearable in what could otherwise be quite unbearable circumstances.

On 25 August, after the government did the backflip in respect of housing and also funerals, an open letter signed by the Shadow Minister for Defence and the Shadow Minister for Defence Science and Personnel was sent to the Minister for Defence and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. It is worth while looking at some of the issues raised in that open letter. They say:
Our contact with Defence personnel has clearly revealed a serious morale problem which cannot be ignored. Failure to act will immediately affect Australia's military capabilities.

These people do not have to be pandered to, but they do need to be content in the challenges that they face. They go on to say in the open letter to the Minister for Defence and the minister assisting:

We are particularly concerned at the ruling by the Tax Office that members of the ADF are the same as all other employees. As you would be aware, this flies in the face of the evidence and the way in which previous Governments have treated defence personnel who serve this nation.
That is the key. There is a difference. They are different and you cannot now go lumping them into the same barrel as every other group.

talk.start.para: —We don't.
—Well, I will come to that in a minute. It goes on to say:

speech.para: What other group of employees are unable to access normal industrial laws and processes, are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week, are never paid overtime, are subject to the Defence Force Discipline Act, are compulsorily posted and can be sent to war at any time?

There are people in these defence forces who are on 24-hour readiness. There are those who are on seven days. There are those who are on 28 days. There are no people on similar levels of readiness out there in the general public. It is a nonsense. It does not exist. So to say that Defence personnel are the same as others out there in the community is not true at all. The open letter goes on to say:

The conditions of service that currently apply to members of the ADF were put in place in order to compensate them for the inherent hardships of service life and their conditions of employment. They are not fringe benefits or perks and the public realises this.
The open letter to the ministers goes on:

From advice that personnel have received from the ADF, it is clear that many face increased child support and superannuation surcharge liabilities and reduced entitlements to family payments as a result of the requirements that fringe benefits are reported on an individual's taxation group certificate.

One can see from this that there is an appeal being made to the Minister for Defence and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence to address this issue in a realistic way, not to try to sweep it under the carpet and not to try to ignore it.

With the modern age of emails and computers, we have all received a number of emails on this particular subject, none more so than me. It is worth while looking at the sentiments as expressed by one of the persons who corresponded with me. This person says:

1. It is with great concern to myself and my family, on the effect that the fringe benefits tax (FBT) will have on us. I am currently serving in Sydney, and because of personal reasons, my family (wife and four children) are required to live in Cairns. I have been told that the FBT on the married quarters and the single accommodation that I occupy—
and I note that that has been addressed by the government—
. . . could amount to as much as $22,000.00. On top of this, there will be FBT on remote locality leave, service vehicles, entitled travel—
contrary to what Senator Abetz's advice is—
airconditioning allowance, recreational leave travel, plus numerous others. These few FBT's will easily amount to approximately another $14,000.00, adding another $36,000.00 to my grossed up salary.

If you take out the accommodation that this person writes to me about of some $22,000, $14,000 is even then not an insignificant amount of money that will be included in this person's group certificate. He goes on to say:
2. This will in turn affect my family in the following areas:
a. Family payment
b. Youth allowance
c. Childcare assistance
d. Liability for superannuation contributions
e. Liability for medicare surcharge
f. And liability for child support—
The person does have a sense of humour in spite of being faced with these extra charges. He adds in brackets:
(if my wife and I are ever separated).
In the face of adversity, there is at least a little humour in this letter. He continues:

3. The only positive at the moment, is that my wife and I are still married, if we did separate I would be in the same position as many other members of the Defence Force, forced to resign because of this FBT!

That is not contrived. If one looks at the leader page that came with it, one will see that it got widespread distribution throughout the House of Representatives and the Senate, regardless of people's political persuasion in this place or the other place. One can only say that it is being felt out there. What I found when I travelled around Defence Force bases recently meeting Defence Force personnel was that there is grave concern about what is happening and what is being done by the government in this area.
I will now address some of the issues that are attracting fringe benefits tax. I quote from a document from the Defence Force and headed `Chief executive instructions—part 5, annex A to chapter 5':
ITEMS WHICH ATTRACT A FRINGE BENEFITS TAX LIABILITY

The following, listed in order of liability magnitude, are payments, allowances or benefits provided by Defence to its employees or former employees that have been identified as being partially or fully subject to FBT.
The first one on the list is housing. That has been addressed; I concede that. The second one reads:
Living Away From Home Allowance (Defence FBT Manual-chapter 9)
- Continuing Overseas Allowance (COA)—
remember that this is an internal Defence document—
- Living Out Allowances (LOA) and Living Out Away From Home Allowance (LOAFHA)
- Overseas Living Allowance (OLA)
- Child Supplement Allowance
- Reunion Supplement Allowance
Expense payments (Defence FBT Manual-chapter 7)
- Entitlement travel
- discharge travel
- annual recreation leave travel
- leave-other travel
- remote locality leave travel
- remote locality family leave travel
- reverse remote locality leave travel
- reunion travel
- student reunion travel
- spouse emergency travel

There is a whole range of services which are very much part and parcel of defence life and which they do not see as a perk or a lurk but as an unalienable right and something which should not be subjected to FBT. Yet in Defence's own documentation, it lists those as items which will be subject to and attract FBT. But the list has not stopped; there are three pages of these things put out by the Department of Defence. The list continues:
- Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) payments
- Transfer benefits
- post transfer visits
- allowance for sale of land
- long term Temporary Accommodation Allowance
- education costs allowance
- removals at time of retirement
- Defence Home Owners Scheme
- Other allowances
- child education in Australia allowance
- air conditioning allowance
- extra tuition expenses
- removal related child care reimbursement allowance
- Semi official phones in private residences
- Spouse accompanied travel
- Removals expenditure
- termination of service removals
- change of domestic status

And so it goes on. There is a very long list, which Senator Abetz has obviously not had made available to him. I think someone should make it available to someone in the government so that they will have some idea of the extent of the application as seen by the Department of Defence. It should not be something cobbled together by me or someone else; it should be a Defence document. There is a wide range of services and a wide range of issues that will attract an FBT.

Senator Abetz's answer to that is, `Oh, well, we've taken care of the big item. We've taken care of housing.' So what? There are other items which will affect the lifestyle of people in the defence forces right throughout Australia. I think the government should not be treating this as a political stunt. It is a genuine attempt to look at an issue that has been raised in visits that have been undertaken by me and my colleagues when we have met with defence personnel.

Without going through the whole list, it is worth while just looking at one other email I received, which I think sums up this whole issue. It is an email addressed to senators—some of my colleagues on the other side would have access to it. It says:
The new fringe benefits tax legislation that has been introduced in April this year, (we have only just been made aware of it, and that alone is cause for concern)—
the email is dated 6 August—

is causing a huge amount of concern in the Defence Community. I am a leading Seaman Combat System Operator in the RAN, and would like to draw all of your attentions to the devastating effect these new laws place on the people who risk their lives defending our beloved country, whether that be in times of peace or war.
The writer goes on:

If none of you are familiar with the new legislation, or the impact that this will have, that goes to show exactly how highly regarded it seems, we are to you. If you are aware, why was this allowed to be passed?
The email proceeds:

Please raise your voices as members of our community who are there to better the lives of each of us and look after us, the obedient men and women who love our country and will if need be die for it, if sanctioned by you, the Government, to go to war.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to take up the debate that the opposition has raised in general business. The motion before us is not all bad, I can say. We reject it as a whole, but of course part (a) of Senator Crossin's motion we cannot dispute. It says that the Senate:

speech.para: (a) recognises the unique and harsh conditions under which Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel work and the fact that the ADF is not an ordinary workforce and has never been treated that way by previous governments;

I think the house has consensus on that. We support it. I should add that, particularly in the rural and regional areas, the economic and social benefits that the Australian Defence Force brings to a community is well known. I cite the example of the city of Sale where the now long-time RAAF air base brings employment, prestige and identity to the area—and an economic stimulus, as I mentioned, to say the least. So we support part (a) of Senator Crossin's motion.

But this government should and does allow for the special circumstances that the ADF personnel live under, especially the fact that, as previous speakers have highlighted, they need to move around the country more than any other profession or job would require. They are unique in that aspect and we do recognise it. I cannot think of any other profession in which people have to move around to meet the requirements of their job. For that reason, this government in particular has recognised their unique circumstances—no less than in the 1999 budget, where this government specifically targeted the unique circumstances of Defence personnel.

These are some of the budget measures we undertook in our last budget. For example, we enhanced the operation of the Defence Home Owner Scheme by doubling the maximum subsidised loan to $80,000, or to $160,000 where spouses have a joint entitlement, by reducing the eligibility period for a subsidised loan from six to five years and by making subsidised loans available to active reservists after a qualifying period of eight years effective service. Another initiative by the government in its 1999 budget was to establish the Defence Community Organisation to provide effective and efficient support to defence members and their families. Another initiative was the ADF spouse employment initiative, which will ensure that ADF spouses are provided with a range of measures to reduce employment difficulties caused by their mobile lifestyle.

So you can see that this government does recognise and has recognised the unique working circumstances of our Defence personnel—and their spouses and their families. And that should be the case. Needless to say, through all our budgets since first coming into government in 1996 we have recognised the special position of our Australian Defence Force. In fact, it needs to be said that we quarantined the whole defence budget from cuts. Anyone who can remember back to the 1996 budget knows just how tough that budget was. No department got away without suffering cuts so that we could reduce the legacy of the budget deficit of some $10 billion. But Defence was the only department that did not suffer a cut. Why? Because we recognised—particularly, I should say, the Prime Minister recognised—the worth of the defence forces. Sure, there were internal efficiencies created within that budget but, unlike any other department, Defence was not subjected to cuts. So Senator Crossin failed to recognise this government's contribution to our defence forces as a whole.

In the area of fringe benefits tax, which is taking up the might of this particular debate, the principle that I have just outlined from this government has been upheld. On 19 August, in a joint statement by Minister for Defence John Moore and the Hon. Bruce Scott, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, it was announced that the housing assistance provided to defence force personnel in Australia would be `totally exempted from FBT reporting'—a decision that quite obviously points out that the federal government recognises the unique circumstances of the ADF.

The government's decision reflects the fact that the Defence Force provides housing assistance to personnel not as part of their remuneration package but to allow us to send ADF personnel wherever they are required to serve. By totally exempting ADF members' housing assistance from the reporting measures, the federal government has addressed the primary concern of ADF families. That was their primary concern, and that was some 70 to 80 per cent of the tax they were paying anyway.
