I was intrigued by Senator Hogg's speech just prior to mine when he read out email after email in regard to submissions he had had from Defence Force people complaining about the FBT reporting requirements. He let slip that those emails were in fact dated 6 August or at least prior to 19 August, when the statement that I have just read out was made. Of course they were lobbying very hard to have an exemption made in relation, particularly, to housing assistance. He read them out and failed to tell the Senate that these were lobbying attempts prior to the government's decisions. Well, we have made that decision now. On 19 August we made the decision to exempt the defence personnel housing assistance program from FBT. So I would have to say that Senator Hogg's contribution here is outdated, just like all their other contributions—basically outdated.

I would like to read some of the emails that followed this government's decision, to which I hope Senator Hogg will listen. I hope that he is listening to the internal television coverage, because he was less than frank with this Senate when he read out his emails. Let me read some out from 19 August, the day the government's decisions were made. I would say that these were most likely written by the same people who had been emailing Senator Hogg in their lobbying attempts to have the government make a decision and, when we made the decision, they decided to email us and thank us. Here are just some of the emails that were received by the government:
Thank you for caring. I have just seen the media release on the ADF housing FBT exemption. This decision will make a significant difference to many ADF families.
A second email read:
Dear Sir,
Thank you and your team for the work towards the FBT.

This is from 19 August, Senator Hogg and those on the other side—not from 6 August or whatever date Senator Hogg failed to put on his previous emails. These are the thankyous after our decision, and so you really are making pretty cheap political points, beating up a general business time into something it just is not. The feeling just is not there as it was prior to this government's decision. Let me read another email:
Sir,
Thank you for your personal efforts in having the housing assistance exempt from FBT reporting. Thank you for both Karen and I.
That is obviously his wife. He goes on:
I have just got of the phone to Colonel Steve Jones from LC. He has requested that I pass on the thanks of all the LC for the outcome.
I have to admit that I do not know what `LC' stands for.

talk.start.para: —Lieutenant Colonels—the top of the tree.
—Thank you. It goes on:

speech.para: He will be putting this in writing to General Dunn and Rob Tonkin.

So you can see that the government have been congratulated and recognised for the decision they have made, but not by those on the opposite side: they still think they can make a big issue out of this when it is simply is not there.

It should be noted that there are very many other Defence allowances and benefits already exempt. I would like to read some out that are inclusive of the housing assistance package. There is the air-conditioning allowance, compassionate leave, home purchase and sales expense allowance for all but first purchase and sale on discharge, most removals, transferee travel and accommodation, entertainment, car parking and use of cars for official purposes. These also are exempt from reporting.

However, the government's philosophical or policy position is that we of course have to take into consideration the very special role and conditions of the ADF, and that has been said. ADF personnel are taxpayers and they see what they do as a job—be it far more patriotic than most other jobs. Nevertheless, it is a job for them, and they are taxpayers. So they are open also to the tax advantages that normal income taxpayers would be open to anyway. So I remind the house that these particular members of the defence forces, those on income, will in fact be able to take advantage of the government's $13 billion income tax cuts, which are a result of the tax reform package.

It is worth reminding the house that the effect of the $13 billion will be that 80 per cent of Australians—and that probably includes all of the ADF personnel—will be paying on average 30c in the dollar or less in income tax. That is the effect of the tax advantage, and it needs to be noted that Defence personnel also will be taking advantage of those very welcome tax cuts.

Equally, we believe that there are clear personal benefits in being a member of the Defence Force, so these clear personal benefits should also be taxed. These are: private use of their Commonwealth cars, free flights on Defence aircraft, semi-official phones, HECS payments, recreational free travel, spouse accommodated travel, property prizes and gifts and all those sorts of matters. They are not unique, of course, to the ADF personnel. Many benefits such as those I have just read out are available to civilians and public servants. Education assistance, semi-official phones and spouse accommodated travel are all taxed for the civilian public servant. Therefore, we believe it is fair and equal that the defence forces also be taxed on their clear personal benefits.

Many of that list that I just read out are available to private employees. Ansett and Qantas staff receive subsidised flights that are reported on their group certificates. It has to be asked: why shouldn't the defence forces also have to report them when there is a clear personal benefit and when it is not attached to the position or, as we have conceded, to the unique conditions that Defence personnel must bear. Bank staff get cheap home loans and have to report them as personal benefits on their group certificates. So too should the ADF personnel.

The intention of the FBT reporting legislation is to increase the fairness of the Australian taxation system for all taxpayers. It is designed to ensure that the taxpayer's total remuneration is taken into account when assessing individual liabilities for payments like child support or surcharges or when assessing the need for government benefits like family allowances. The principle is that those members of our community with a capacity to do so should contribute fairly to our taxation base and that government benefits should be targeted at those in greatest need. This is something you would think the other side would support. In fact, they do—they voted for the legislation. We all know their record. They refused to exempt Defence as an organisation for FBT when they first introduced FBT in 1986. You went to the October 1998 election with a policy of widening FBT reporting legislation that you now oppose in relation to the defence forces. You voted for the FBT legislation that you now oppose.

It should also be noted that the government is still considering certain aspects of benefits for the Australian defence forces that we have not ruled out as yet. We are still discussing the status of a number of allowances and benefits in the hope of being able to refine the FBT reporting legislation. Still under discussion is the remote locality leave travel, where ADF personnel or their families posted to remote areas take an occasional flight away from the base to a major population centre like Sydney. We in the National Party, with Senator Boswell at the table, would hope that in discussion with Treasury that is something that the government would seriously consider and perhaps make exempt. That sounds like a good one if you are up there in the far north of Australia.

Other benefits under consideration are education assistance for tertiary students or for children who remain in a location to complete schooling while their parents are posted to another location, and allowances paid to Defence families with special needs. It is not a closed chapter yet. There are important matters still under consideration with Treasury. If they are defined as being attached to the job and are seen as part of the unique nature of being in our defence forces, the government will quite happily exempt them from FBT reporting. Senator Hogg came in here before and read a long list. I am letting him know now that many of the things he read out are still under consideration by the government.

The motion is out of date. The speakers on the other side have clearly come in here with some pretty old speeches. This matter has been a long time getting up, I suppose, for Senator Crossin. They have failed to recognise the decision that the government has made. They are reading out old emails. We all get emails, but Senator Hogg ought to come in here and table his emails. I challenge him to table those emails and we will match them up against the emails I have which are on the day of the decision, and there are plenty of thankyous amongst them. Senator Hogg has just tried to fill in time with his speech. He has given an outdated speech. I ask the next speaker to stand up and give us a really up-to-date speech, now that you have heard me update you all on the fact that the government's decision of 19 August pretty well solved the concerns of the Defence personnel and that there are still matters under serious consideration.

talk.start.para: —I really appreciated Senator McGauran giving us an update, informing us of what exactly is going on and saying that we are outdated. I would like to speak today in support of the motion before the Senate on the impact of the government's new fringe benefits tax reporting regime—a result of the government's new tax system—and about the extreme hardship it imposes on many of our Australian Defence Force personnel. Among the families of our Defence Force there is a great deal of anger, frustration and disillusionment about the recent changes to the fringe benefits tax.

speech.para: This causes me, as with many of my colleagues, to have a great deal of concern for the future of our armed forces. Let us not underestimate the crucial national role per formed by service personnel in this country. Where would we be without them? Not only are these men and women prepared to go into battle to defend the rights of every Australian; they also have an important role to play in counter-terrorist attacks and must be ready to evacuate Australian citizens from anywhere in the world at a moment's notice.

Australian defence personnel do not have a choice where they are employed or where they are deployed; they are at the service of the nation. They are not the same as employees in the work force anywhere in Australia. They are a highly trained specialised work force employed in the defence of Australia and of the citizens of this country. They are a special category of employees and need to be treated as such.

As a result of the impact of changes to the fringe benefits tax, many of them are now having to rethink their current situations and whether or not they can in fact afford to continue to serve their country. As a result of this measure, we could experience mass separations simply because many people will not be able to afford to stay on as members of the armed forces. Currently, the separation rates run at about 13 per cent. These are just manageable but, if this situation is not addressed, we will see these rates increase dramatically. Not only will we see thousands of military personnel leave the defence forces; we will find it extremely difficult to recruit people. This has the potential to have a significant negative impact on Australia's military capabilities.

Failure to exempt Defence Force personnel from the provisions of the fringe benefits tax reporting requirements clearly demonstrates this government's lack of understanding of the unique conditions of service life. The government fails to appreciate the fact that their situation is completely different from that of civilian workers. Unless this government is prepared to recognise the special place that Defence Force families have within the Australian community and that they therefore require special consideration, we are in danger of losing many of our trained personnel.

talk.start.para: —But I did give recognition.

—I am coming to you, Senator McGauran. Let us take a minute to look at some of the difficulties that families in the Defence Force have to face every day but that the majority of Australians never even have to think about. These families are not wealthy. They receive salaries in the low to middle income bracket, they are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week and are never paid overtime. They are unable to access normal industrial laws and processes, are subject to the Defence Force Discipline Act and can be sent to war at any time.

speech.para: They are faced with frequent and compulsory moves based on the operational requirements of the Defence Force and they must be ready to just pick up and move their families at short notice to anywhere that they are needed. This impacts on the whole family life. Of course, relocating one's family every so often can be quite traumatic. Adults can adjust to this far more easily than children. Children are forced to change schools, which forces them to leave behind any friends that they have managed to make since the last time they had to move.

Anyone who has had to move for whatever reason and, as a result, has had to see their children change schools knows that it is not always easy for children to adjust. Yet the men and women of our armed forces continually make these moves time and time again for the service of their nation. This alone can put a tremendous amount of additional strain on the family relationship. One can hardly argue that these are the normal employment conditions afforded to the rest of Australia, yet this government refuses to see Defence Force families as having a special place within the Australian community. Nor will the government recognise the need to address their requirements as employees who are different from other Australian workers. Instead, this government continues to ignore the fact that the vast majority of allowances that the service personnel receive are to compensate them and their families for the unique circumstances pertaining to service life.

The child-care reimbursement allowance, spouse emergency travel, child education allowance, family and service reunion travel and remote locality leave travel are only a few of the allowances and benefits which will attract a fringe benefits tax. The Defence Force Chief Executive's instructions list over 40 allowances and benefits which will attract the fringe benefits reporting requirements. Earlier my colleague Senator Hogg outlined most of these benefits quite extensively. We are talking of legitimate conditions of service that were put in place to compensate members of the Defence Force for their conditions of employment and the inherent hardships of service life.

Under this legislation, these allowances will be classed as fringe benefits for Defence Force personnel and will be taken into account for the purposes of the social security means test and for taxation surcharges, such as the Medicare levy, HECS and superannuation. This means that many people in the defence forces will be massively disadvantaged when their incomes are grossed up. Many families will no longer be entitled to family allowance payments or will face increased child support and superannuation surcharge liabilities.

The previous speaker, Senator McGauran, spoke of certain exemptions which the government has considered alleviating, such as for housing and other allowances. On this side of the chamber, we commend the government for doing that—if indeed it has—but we will not be happy until the more than 40 benefits are exempt from FBT reporting requirements for Defence Force personnel. I hope the government is looking at all of them, and not just at a few. It is not good enough to just look at a few. This is extremely important to these people. It is a unique thing. Not everybody is prepared to serve their country by working in the defence forces, basically because of the upheaval to family life. It certainly is not a normal way of life.

Senator McGauran also spoke of how members of the Defence Force were taxpayers. Of course they are taxpayers. They pay their taxes, just as we all pay taxes, but they are not exactly highly paid—they are not up there with the wealthy or the elite of this country. They are average working people and they work very hard at their jobs. They pay their taxes, but they are entitled to extra benefits and conditions because they are a unique and essential part of our community. They are working for us, for the nation and for the benefit of all the citizens of this country. The government must recognise that members of the Australian Defence Force are in a unique position and are, therefore, entitled to benefits to compensate for the extraordinary lifestyle that they and their families are forced to lead.

talk.start.para: —As I have been at another meeting, I was unable to hear what was said by opposition members at the commencement of this debate on benefits for Australian Defence Force personnel. I came in in time to hear only the end of Senator Gibbs's contribution—which was obviously prepared well in advance. I promise you that my contribution has not been because I have been quite busy—as Senator Quirke would know—at another meeting. However, I did note one or two of the things that Senator Gibbs said. The one thing she did not say was who on earth introduced this fringe benefits tax in the first place. To the best of my knowledge, it was the Labor Party.

speech.para: When the Labor Party introduced the fringe benefits tax legislation in 1986, it refused to exempt Defence as an organisation. Senator Gibbs was not here and neither was I—and, thankfully, neither was Senator Quirke. However, when introducing the fringe benefits tax, the Labor Party refused to exempt Defence, as an organisation, from FBT. As I understand it, the Australian Labor Party also went to an election in 1998 with a policy of widening the FBT reporting legislation—the same conditions that members opposite are now opposed to. They voted then for the FBT legislation which they now oppose.

I am sorry I did not hear the speakers who spoke before Senator Gibbs, but I am sure that many of them said exactly the same things she said. You have cried crocodile tears about the FBT but you had ample opportunities to change the legislation. At any time, the Labor Party could have said that in future the defence forces would be exempt from FBT. It did not want to do that. It wanted to retain the capacity that was always there once the legislation was passed in 1986. Members of the Labor Party never moved an amendment to that legislation and at no time did they state an intention to exempt Australian Defence Force personnel. Only now, when the issue has hit the headlines again because of rulings from the Australian Taxation Office, do they try to play on the fears of Australian Defence Force personnel and their families.

I am very conscious of the life led by Australian Defence Force personnel. The wife of a member of the Defence Force is on my staff and so I am quite aware of the importance of the supplementary payments and allowances that are made to Defence Force personnel and their effect on their retention in the armed forces. The Labor Party has decided that, having not fixed this up in 1986 when in government, it will now make a big song and dance about the whole thing as though it has just realised that something new has happened. What has happened is that the tax office has made a ruling in relation to FBT.

I am aware of the impact that that is having on Defence Force personnel. When someone joins the Defence Force they do it with the understanding that there will be certain forms of remuneration. They all understand what that remuneration is and what it has been over a number of years. When changes are being made that might adversely affect them, it is only natural that they will want to express some concern and do something about it.

Senator Gibbs spoke about the upheaval to family life. Those who join the Australian defence forces—Army, Navy or Air Force—are well aware that at some stage during their career they could be posted anywhere in Australia. They do not go in with their eyes shut. They know that once they join the armed forces, even if they have a family, at some stage in their career they will have to move. I think it is going over the top to talk about upheaval to family life because any number of people in any number of professions will, during their working life, have to move interstate or from country town to city or vice versa. They do not call that an upheaval to their family life. In many cases, it is a chance for preferment or betterment.

This upheaval to family life that Senator Gibbs talks about is something that always has been and always will be normal in the life of people who choose the Australian Defence Force for their career—and some very fine careers there have been. It is a career that we hope many Australians aspire to. Our defence forces are held in very high regard, both by the Australian community and by people who know them and who have seen them serve overseas, both in times of peace and in times of war. So, when it comes to the taxation treatment of Australian Defence Force personnel, whenever there is a change, it is only natural that there will be a reaction from those who are going to be affected. There will also be a reaction from the government if it sees that people are going to be adversely affected by changes in the rulings of the Australian Taxation Office.

Let me give you an example of how the government is reviewing this matter and will continue to review it as more information comes to light. The greatest impact was on housing assistance where people have greatly subsidised rents. They deserve those subsidised rents because a disadvantage of joining the Australian Defence Force is that they are constantly on the move. Many of them choose not to purchase a house because they would like to know where they will finish up before they make that decision.

Recent decisions of the Australian Defence Force to situate many of their personnel in northern Australia—in particular, in places like Darwin and Townsville where rents are exceptionally high—mean it is only fair that a person who has no say in where they are going—where they are posted to is at the whim of their superiors—should get housing rental assistance. They have to live in rented accommodation where the rent is much higher than what they would normally expect to pay had they stayed in their town of origin. As Australian Defence Force personnel they are put in a position that no other member of the community is necessarily put into. That was taken into account when the government announced that it would totally exempt from FBT the housing assistance that is paid to our Defence service men and women. The non-reporting of a wide range of other Defence allowances recognises the unique demands that are placed on our service men and women as they serve in various placements throughout Australia.

Senator Quirke and I, as part of the Senate Foreign Affairs and Trade Defence Subcommittee, visited many of these establishments in the northern part of Australia only about a month ago. We were able to talk with some of the people who were in receipt of these allowances. It is the role of that subcommittee to listen to what the Defence Force personnel are saying and where they feel that they have been unjustly treated. Senator Quirke will remember our talking to one of the people at an unmanned base at Sherger, who said that, because he was posted there in a caretaker position, he was out of pocket to the tune of something like $8,000 compared with his previous posting to the Tindal air base near Katherine. Because we were able to visit these places and listen to the Defence Force personnel, we can take that issue up. It is certainly one of those things that will happen in relation to many of the allowances that Senator Gibbs listed off if Defence Force personnel feel they will be disadvantaged as against their current position.

We place a very high priority on the retention rate in the defence forces. Many young people who choose a Defence Force career, at some stage in their later life—having received training and a certain expertise in an area or a trade—may choose to leave the forces and practise that trade elsewhere. The investment and time that is put into training is not then retained by the defence forces. It is obvious that we need to offer some significant incentives so that the retention rates of those people on whom a considerable amount of money is spent teaching them either a trade or to be good soldiers remain high. There is a wide range of things in the Defence Force that people are required to do, and there is a wide range of things that they can learn to become proficient in, whether it be in a trade or a skill or even degrees of other learning. It is important that we do try to retain those people in the defence forces at the full quota determined by the Australian government and the Defence department. We know that it is important they are retained, Senator Gibbs, and I am sure that some of the issues you raised in your speech—and, as I said, I only heard the end of it—are issues which this government will look at once the explanations are given as to the effect that the new rulings by the tax office will have on those people who serve Australia in the defence forces throughout the whole country.

The opposition's suggestion that there should be a total exemption of all reporting is irresponsible; it is not good public policy. I understand the difficulties that arise when some of the FBT reported amounts are put on group certificates and that they may affect other family supplements that some service personnel are entitled to. I am sure that is something the government will continue to look into when they find out the full ramifications of the decision of the tax office.

Some of the statements that have been made by the shadow spokesmen, including Mr Martin, show they have already recognised that there are some things that should be reported. They have already recognised that the general's car is an issue that should be reported. Although there is a need to provide some incentive so that people who stay in the forces are not financially disadvantaged, there needs to be a line drawn where we do not go overboard by making sure that people in the defence forces are able to receive benefits that simply are not available to other people in the community—benefits they could not claim to be part of the compensation for the lifestyle of being in the defence forces. I think there are some things that should be reported. Although they are Defence Force personnel, they are also members of the Australian community, and I think they should be treated in exactly the same way with respect to some issues.

It is this government's job to try to determine which things should be reported and included under the existing legislation—legislation which the Labor Party introduced. Of course, the Labor Party did not want to have any exemptions, so it is now up to the current government to try to sort out these things for the Defence service personnel. I am sure that all of those things that you raised, Senator Gibbs, will be subject to some sort of review as we go through the whole list. I think that the opposition's call to exempt all ADF personnel from the FBT reporting requirements is quite illogical when you look at the treatment of other allowances by previous governments, including the Labor government when it was in power, and by the current government.

I have here copies of some emails in which people have congratulated the government on its exemption of housing from FBT treatment. There are a number of people within the Defence Force who, I am quite sure, know that this government is going to do all in its power to make sure that the things that are required to be changed will be reviewed. In fact, I am sure that there will be an ongoing review and that the government will continue to closely monitor the effect of rulings that have been made.

A number of Defence allowances are already exempt and not reportable, and there is no intention to change any of those. Because many of our personnel are required to move from the southern areas up to Darwin and Townsville, there is an airconditioning allowance and an allowance for compassionate travel. The treatment of compassionate travel will not change. There is no move afoot to change the treatment of the home purchase and sales expense allowance for all but first purchases and sales on discharge. That will still be exempt and not reportable. As I understand it, almost all removals—and I cannot think of an instance when removals are not taken into consideration—are already exempt and will not be reportable. You would expect transfer travel and accommodation to be exempt, and this government is going to make sure that that happens.

I know that the Department of Defence and the government are discussing with the Treasury the status of a number of the other Defence Force allowances and benefits to refine just how the FBT reporting legislation applies to ADF personnel in the future. A number of those allowances and benefits are still under discussion, and there are some very important ones. I have a staff member who was a recipient of an allowance because her husband—an Air Force pilot—was on an overseas exchange for 2½ years. So I know how important the overseas living allowance paid to Defence families is. Sometimes it is the only way they can actually afford to accept an exchange which, by getting the experience of serving with another force overseas, will improve their career. So I am one who is quite close to the effect of these changes, and I will certainly be monitoring them closely.

My colleague Senator Quirke, as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—in which I also have a role—knows that this is a matter that will be discussed, and has been discussed in the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade as recently as Tuesday night. It is an issue that we will continue to monitor because it is in the interests of all of us to have a highly efficient and competent Defence Force. That means that we must do all in our power to make sure that we retain as many personnel as are deemed by the Department of Defence to be necessary to meet requirements. This government will always make sure that it does things that are in the best interests of the Australian Defence Force because we realise just how important it is not only to the personnel who work within those armed services but also to the country as a whole.

My time is drawing to a close. There are not many other things that I want to say, except to reiterate what I said when I first started, and that is that the fringe benefits tax was a child of the Labor Party. It had an opportunity in the time that it was in power to exempt the Defence Force if it had felt that exempting the Defence Force was so important and that all reportable payments should not be made. I simply ask the question: if it is so important to the Labor Party, why didn't it exempt the Defence Force from fringe benefits tax in the first place? If it had, we would not be having this debate this afternoon.

The Labor Party brought on this motion to try to stir up some public support, forgetting its own complicity in the original legislation that came before this parliament. It is trying to draw some partisan support when in fact there should be a strong bipartisan approach to all matters relating to the Defence Force and to subjects like this. I hope that, when these matters are debated in the chamber in the future, we will see a bipartisan approach in order to make sure that the Defence Force of Australia is a defence force that we are proud of and that those who work in the Defence Force feel comfortable with the conditions that they work under.

talk.start.para: —I think we ought to take a quick look at fringe benefits and what this issue is about. Senator Ferguson is right: it was a child of the last Labor government. Fringe benefits tax legislation was brought in in 1986. I remember it well. Indeed, it was brought in to stop, at that stage, a growing source of tax evasion which was accessed primarily by certain elements in society—usually at the top end of the income stream.
—That would be you, Quirkey.

—No, Senator, it was not me. I could not afford to take my missus out on a Sunday in the tax deductible Mercedes to Ayers House—which was also tax deductible. Unfortunately, I could not quite pull that one off.

speech.para: This legislation was brought in, it was very broad brush and, as Senator Ferguson said, it had a large impact. But it wasn't long before there were a few other creative schemes out there. In a previous existence I was the chair of what was known as the economic and finance committee of the South Australian parliament. The Liberal Party moved a motion there one day that we have a look at executive salaries of the statutory corporations—that is, those that reported directly to the then South Australian government. This was an interesting challenge.

Before the resolution ink was dry on the paper I had a phone call from the then head of the State Bank to tell me that he hoped we were not going to inquire too much more into the bank because morale was pretty low. About a week later a group of his people came down to see me and it wasn't too long before I worked out what the game was. In the case of this particular individual, he was not paid as much as Mr Marcus Clarke but he was still paid $370,000 a year. This is 1992.

talk.start.para: —Not bad.

—No, it wasn't bad, Senator West. What was really good about it was that he put $178,000 into super and got an $80,000-odd tax deduction. He had loyal officers down there in the room telling me that they didn't want us to have a look at superannuation. Then came the Jaguar. One fellow in one of the statutory corporations had a Jaguar, another car, and a Laser for his daughter. I am not talking about a laser printer—I am talking about a car. In fact, of his $140,000 package, he was only getting $19,000 in cash and he was on the family assistance supplement. That is what this stuff was brought in to stop. There have been several attempts in the 1990s to try to rein in the fringe benefits that have been paid out there.
—What union was he in, again?

—I don't know. He was in an insurance company, the SGIC. I am not sure, Minister, through you, Mr Deputy President, whether he took his union dues off that $19,000 as well. It is possible; he could have. He was certainly into everything else—car parks, the whole lot—and presumably even his copy of the Truth because, if ever he reads this, he will know exactly what I am referring to.

speech.para: Successive governments have attempted to put integrity into the tax system. I will not knock the present government for attempting to do that as well. They know that it is necessary for the integrity of the tax system and for the morale of the taxpayer that people in this country have confidence that the system is fair and equitable. I don't think there is any argument about that. That is why the opposition here took an approach to this, as Senator Ferguson outlined before, at the last election and during the 1990s to scrutinise the question of reportability of fringe benefits.

Unfortunately, in this exercise we have roped in a group of workers in this country who in many respects not only deserve our support and but also at whose remuneration we ought to have a much closer look. In Defence, instead of paying appropriate salaries—and I blame both sides of politics for this—we have relied on all of the different benefits that have gone to these serving men and women in the Defence Force. We have said: `Instead of getting a pay rise of X number of dollars, we will put in place a series of benefits that will give you the same amount of money, less the taxation.'

I don't want to go into it too far. I think a lot of politicians understand this system because that is how the electoral allowance was used in years gone by—to achieve the same sort of effect with politicians' salaries. Members of the Defence Force are going to be suddenly pulled up. We are not certain yet about the government's 19 August announcement that it has wiped out the entire problem; it appears that it has only wiped out some elements of it and that there are others still under review. That is certainly what the government speakers have been saying here today. We now know that if those fringe benefits figures are placed on the group certificate and are used for the calculation of a number of social security benefits that may accrue to spouses, the old child endowment as we used to call it, or for those unfortunate enough to have gone through divorce—which is a feature, unfortunately, of defence life; I will go into that in a moment—and to need child support payments, then there is going to be a very serious problem.

It is all very well for some senators to come in here and read out different emails, as Senator McGauran did, from the `LCs' as he called them. I presume that is the lieutenant colonels. They are going to be up round $70,000 or $80,000 a year. I am not sure how much a lieutenant colonel is paid but I am sure it is an awful lot more than an ordinary soldier, sailor or airman whose family is probably reliant on the various benefits that have been paid. Unless we are careful with this, we will cause an irreversible breakdown in the morale in the Defence Force and we will lose highly trained professional people who put up with a great deal. They put up with postings that are invariably in what we would call hardship areas.

I fully support the shift to Darwin. I think it is a great idea. I am pleased I do not have to have anything to do with it. I have nothing against Darwin; I am sure Darwin is a lovely place for six months of the year. For the other six months of the year it is wet, hot and horrible. The jungle is not much better for a lot of these people. It is not much better for a number of personnel who have to go on overseas postings to such great postcard places as Rwanda and Bougainville. I am sure these people are actually experiencing considerable hardship. To have these sorts of things done to them is just not on.

I am pleased Senator Ferguson finished his address by saying that all of these issues are going to be scrutinised by the government. That indicates to me—and I hope I am right—that Senator Ferguson, as chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, will be personally scrutinising the matters to make sure that our Defence personnel are not subject to these sorts of things.

I will conclude because I am aware of the time and I want to give a couple of my colleagues a chance to say a few words on this issue. I hope that Defence personnel are not going to be in the same position as a large number of others who have come into my office and said, `It is not worth working.' These are ordinary people.

I remember one fellow who was a middle manager at General Motors Holden in Adelaide, earning about $34,000, with two children. He worked out that by the time the Child Support Agency had got through with him all he had left was $90 a week. Unfortunately, the way around it for him was to say, `I do not want to work anymore because if I do I am actually poorer.' I tried to counsel him. I tried to tell him that this is not the approach he should take. It is human nature that people who feel they are working for nothing soon refuse to work. That is what we on this side of politics are frightened of for our Defence Force. This urgently needs proper review.

talk.start.para: —It is with a bit of sadness that I rise to address this issue tonight. We have seen the Defence Force come under very severe attack from this government in recent years. We have seen the defence reform package come in with all its implications. We have had major downsizing of the Defence Force and with that the consequential flow-on which has been lack of morale and uncertainty. We have seen significant numbers of people retrenched from the military. That has not done very good things to the morale within the Defence Force.

speech.para: This is the final straw. I was with some of my colleagues on an inspection at Enoggera and Townsville a couple of weeks ago. Without a doubt this was the issue that was raised. It was raised by all ranks in the ADF, from junior soldiers, sailors and airmen right through to the very senior ranks. This was before they removed the defence housing assistance from consideration under the FBT. This is leaving people with major problems and major impacts upon their lives.

You have heard from my colleagues that members of the Defence Force do not work an eight-hour day, five days a week. It is a 24 hour a day, seven day a week, 365 days a year job. Some of them are basically on call. Small groups of them are ready for conflict now. We are seeing increases in readiness of a number of brigades. This has an impact on the morale not only of the troops but also of their families. Separation is becoming an issue. In certain speciality areas separation rates have risen quite considerably.

One of the things we worked on when we were in government in the 1980s was the impact the families had on separation and the disenchantment the families felt because of the service life the spouse was leading. That certainly led to many separations in the Defence Force. We now have the situation where the Defence Force has had to reintro duce bonuses to those working in the shortage areas. The shortages are often in speciality areas and areas where people have specialist qualifications and skills that are very marketable outside. In return for their service, after a number of years they get additional money.

I do not think this government has looked at the impact the FBT will have on these bonuses. This is going to push some of these people into the area where they will be forced to pay the superannuation surcharge—that is the tax you have when you do not have a tax, which was introduced by this government. It will have an impact upon their Child Support Agency requirements and obligations. These are all issues that this government has failed to take into account. We know that separation—that is, the dissolution of partnerships and relationships—in this country is the highest for those people who happen to be members of the Defence Force. These measures are going to place further stress, concern and worry on Defence Force personnel.

There are a couple of expense payments and benefits that I want to look at in particular, to highlight and talk about why they are going to have an impact and why I have been working very hard over the last 15 years to overcome these problems. One is the child education allowance. People will say defence families get money so their kids can have tuition. What people forget, if they are not familiar with families that are mobile across this country, is that education in this country occurs across six states and two territories. There are still eight different education systems. This allowance goes part way to enable families with children to actually have those children in a position where they can get tuition to catch up with and be on the same level as their peers in the state into which they have moved.

One needs to remember that in this country we do not have a common starting age for school. We still have a ludicrous situation occurring on occasions—I thought we had fixed it 10 years ago—because when children start school in Queensland they have to have turned five, I think it is in the previous December or it might be during that January. In most of the other states children can start at four and nine months or four and 10 months.

I am aware of families who have had the situation where, because they have had a posting forced upon them in the middle of the year, their children have started school in a place such as Victoria, the service spouse has been transferred to Queensland and, when the family gets there, despite the fact that the child might have been in school for a number of months, they are still told—and I was told of a case that happened last year—`The child is too young to start school in Queensland. We will not accept your child.' It is still up to the prerogative of officials in that particular state. These are the sorts of reasons why we need a number of these allowances, particularly ones that relate to education.

We do not have the same name in the education system for the class at which children commence school. It can be preparation, transition, kindergarten or year 1. We do not have the same number of years in high schools across this country. We have curriculum variations so that you can get children who might well be in their early years of high school moving from one state to another thinking that they can study a particular maths because the name is the same, or economics or geography, whatever, but the curriculum between those states and territories is not the same. One of the benefits that these children and their families are allowed to access, and which helps those children, is going to be included, unless the government does a rethink.

The most stupid thing of all in relation to education in this country is that handwriting styles in each state vary, so that, when children move from state to state, state to territory or territory to territory, they are told that they cannot write like that, that they have to change their handwriting style. And you wonder why parents get upset and frustrated about all the moves they have to make. You wonder why they value very highly education allowances that they can access for their children. They are obviously being dismissed by this government as being of no major significance.

Add to that, if you have a child with a disability, what the additional problems are for those families moving. Most states have waiting lists for disability services within their education system and their health system. If you have a child diagnosed as having a learning problem, that diagnosis has probably taken 12 to 18 months. The program has been working very nicely for six months and then at the end of the year it is time to move into a new school. The school may or may not believe what material comes with the child from its previous school and from its previous counsellors. You then lose that period of time while again they go through, `Oh, no, but our system is different; ours is better,' while this child is reassessed. Then, given the appropriate referrals, a program is drawn up. It is probably the same sort of program that they had previously, but, because they have moved to a different state, there has been a break in the period of time that this child should have been receiving that program. This must and does have an impact upon that child's learning.

Also, it has an impact upon the family because they know that in two, three or four years time they could well be faced with the same prospect of having to up stumps, move to another state and start the rigmarole all over again: going through the assessment process, getting a program, getting a plan, getting things sorted out. It is a problem. It should not be allowed to happen. I think this government should be criticised most stridently for not taking this into consideration, for not estimating what the impact was going to be. In their usual form, what they have done is acted and then said, `Woops! We've got a problem. We'll look at it and we'll keep nibbling away and making changes.' The government are great for having reviews after they have done something and then have to retrieve the situation.
I condemn this government for the moves they have made and for their failure to understand and comprehend the needs of Defence Force personnel.

talk.start.para: —As a member of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I too have had quite a deal to do with Defence families and I am well aware of the circumstances and arrangements as far as FBT is concerned. For instance, as Senator Crossin said earlier, the situation in Darwin where we have defence housing is that if anybody wanted to go up there and rent privately it would be out of the question. The cost of housing in Darwin is absolutely horrendous. It is a huge problem for defence housing to be able to provide the right type of housing. Suffice to say, the standard of housing being provided by defence housing these days is light years in front of what was provided in the past, to the credit of this government.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 30 June 1999, on motion of Senator Crane:
That the recommendation contained in the committee's report, to refer issues raised in the report to the Procedure Committee, be adopted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I was very quick to spring to my feet. We seem to be racing through these reports and I did not want this matter to leave the Notice Paper without having the opportunity to speak to it. Senators may recall that the motion relates to a supplementary estimates report from the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. This matter was the subject of considerable debate during the truncated debate we had on the financial bills that were dealt with at the end of the last session. As a result, senators on this side were not able to give their full attention to all of the matters that arose from those estimates.

speech.para: It is rather sad to see that the chair of the committee, Senator Crane, has made recommendations arising from that estimates process to the Procedure Committee which, it seems to me, would have the effect of limiting the ability of the estimates committee to inquire into the operations of departments. We pointed out in the debate that one of the suggestions was that you could not refer to any matter that was not contained within the financial year of the subject of the portfolio budget statement. As I understand Senator Crane's position, you could not ask for material which would give the Senate and therefore the community a reference point from the past against which the performance of the department, and indeed the government, could be made at that time.

There is also what I consider to be the potentially ridiculous outcome for certain questions we asked about the financial planning of the department during the financial year. The import of the answers that we received was that perhaps all of that information would not be fully known until, in effect, the end of the financial year, which would have meant that it would only really have been available to us in estimates of the financial year following. If one followed the proposal from the chairman, we would then not have been able to ask questions about the matter that the department could not answer during the current financial year because in next financial year's portfolio budget statement we would be referring to the previous financial year.

As I understand the import of Senator Crane's proposal, we would be out of time to ask the questions. I suppose that would give the department—I am not saying that they would seek to do this—the opportunity to stonewall on the provision of information and then, if the chair's proposal is accepted, a rule would be applied which would prevent us from gaining the information through the estimates process that we had been denied because the department was not able or willing to provide during the currency of the financial year the subject of the portfolio budget statement which was before the committee.

So there were issues which were sought to be canvassed during that estimates process which I and Senator Mackay dealt with in the appropriations debate. I refer senators to the comments that we made then which indicated that the minister at the table, Senator Macdonald, was not prepared to provide information. Frankly, he did not do himself any service in the way he handled his role in the committee and attracted so much adverse comment.

I have been waiting for some time for Senator Macdonald to come into this chamber and in fact challenge what was said. These comments that I am referring to were made at the end of June and we are now approaching the end of August. There has been a considerable amount of time during which Senator Macdonald could have come in here and put his point of view on the matter. There have been a great many adjournment opportunities and other opportunities, but he has not taken them. The only conclusion one can reach is that he does not have anything to put which would contradict the matters which were put on the record by me and Senator Mackay.

Here we have, firstly, an estimates process which was totally unsatisfactory to the opposition because of the behaviour of the minister at the table and, secondly, a proposal by the chair of the committee, Senator Crane, to limit the opportunities of the estimates process in this area in the future. That would be an even worse outcome from the point of view of this opposition, and I suppose I should remind the government that no government remains in power forever. It would also be a matter which would impact upon their ability to scrutinise a future Labor government—and there will be one. However cocky the government are about their position, they would have to realise that governments change; governments become oppositions and oppositions become governments. So it is a very short-sighted approach by the government to try to change the rules in such a way as to limit the effectiveness of the estimates process.

There are other matters that are raised at estimates and some government senators question whether they should be raised there. They are questions which I know I have asked and which, for example, Senator Collins has asked this committee relating to perform ances of government departments and statutory authorities on particular issues.

I have asked questions of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and that has been a matter of public comment recently, particularly about the appointment of a relatively highly paid officer. The questions I asked about the appointment of Mr Foley have led to an inquiry by the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. I must say that it is an inquiry into themselves—and that is not satisfactory—but, nevertheless, it is an inquiry, and Mr Foley has stood aside from his position while that has been taking place. We have also, as I understand it, had some comments by Minister Anderson which indicate that he is viewing the circumstances of the matter very seriously.

If the estimates process were limited in the way that I understand it is suggested by Senator Crane's proposals, we would not have been able to deal with that matter. I think that would lead to a lack of accountability by the authority and a restriction of the process which demonstrably achieves accountability.

I have a constituent in Tasmania whose husband was killed arguably as a result of some inaction. I am reluctant to ascribe the word `negligence' to it because the matter is the subject of legal proceedings, but the rights of my constituent have been assisted by pursuing through the estimates process the incident which caused the death of her husband. Obtaining on the public record information which, in most likelihood, would never have been made public is a matter of accountability of a government authority, and that has been achieved through the estimates process. It is a matter of accountability which will possibly lead to a member of the public obtaining redress through the legal system—redress which would not otherwise have been able to have been pursued. I think this matter should remain on the Notice Paper, so I seek leave to continue my remarks.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 27 May 1999, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to this report of the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee, a committee chaired by my Democrat colleague Senator Allison. This is quite a significant report, and I rise to speak on it mainly to try to emphasise the significance and importance of it. Many times in this chamber we are overwhelmed by paper, reports, responses, documents and all sorts of things. At this time of the week, when we are going through them all at a great rate of knots, it demonstrates how many different types of reports and documents there are around, and often some of the very significant ones can get a little lost amongst the crush. So I think it is important to single this one out as being a significant report on a significant issue.

speech.para: For many years, the Democrats have called for a stronger and more coherent approach on environmental issues at the national level. In the Democrats' view, environment issues are too significant to be left to the vagaries of individual state or local government regimes. That does not mean there is no role for state or local governments—indeed there is a crucial role, particularly for local government, in my view—to ensure that there is better environmental protection. There was an example in the speech I gave in this place yesterday in relation to the Gold Coast City Council and an issue they were facing which had quite significant environmental impacts. But it does need, and we do need, in the Democrats' view, a stronger and more coherent overall set of uniform national standards, a more clearly identifiable set of powers and powers that are strong enough to be able to be used easily, clearly and effectively so that the very significant environmental obligations our country has are met. This committee report, which came at the end of a fairly comprehensive and significant investigation of the issues, does go into that in a significant degree of detail and it provides some very good recommendations.

It was coincidental but nonetheless quite relevant and symbolic, if you like, that not long after this report was tabled the Senate considered and passed the Environment Protection Biodiversity and Conservation Bill, a bill of some controversy. But one of the key aspects of that bill and of the changes that were made to it—with the amendments that the Democrats achieved in getting passed—was to ensure that there was not a weakening of Commonwealth environment powers. There is some dispute about that amongst some people, but the Democrats are of a belief that we have managed to achieve that. Obviously, we will see, as the act comes into operation and starts being utilised, whether we are accurate in that belief. Certainly, we believe that is the case. It is something we paid a lot of attention to.

It is not simply a matter of saying, `The Commonwealth is good and the states are bad.' I think that is a trap and a piece of rhetoric that people often fall into. I have probably been guilty of it myself. Coming from Queensland and having endured many years of National Party government, it is probably not surprising that I have a bit of an aversion to giving too much power to state governments. Clearly, any sorts of government at state and federal levels can be good or bad, and there is nothing necessarily inherently better about either level. What is important is that there is a clear set of uniform standards and a usable set of legislative powers. That is not to cut the states out of their role. We believe that balance was achieved with the amendments made to the Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Bill. Most important, and where it jells with this report, is the ability, with that bill being passed, for ongoing work and improvements. The Democrats certainly do not believe that we now have the perfect act, that everything is fine; we think there is a hell of a lot of room for improvement still. But the framework is now in place for more effective improvements to be built on the foundation that is there in a much easier way than using the various disconnected acts that were in place or that currently exist that will be replaced by the new act when it comes into force next year.

We have moved some way down the track. This report, in broader terms, talks about why it is important that we do move further down that track. There are recommendations about how to do that and what sorts of definitions and boundaries of Commonwealth environment powers we need to have. I think it is an area that needs specific attention. The Democrats—as all people would now be aware—have moved into a stronger position in the balance of power in this chamber than we have had for a few years. Certainly, as the party's environment spokesperson, I am very keen to ensure that we use our position in that balance of power, where we are able to—

talk.start.para: —You don't have the balance of power; you are in coalition with the government,

—to ensure that environmental issues are put back much more at the top of the political agenda than they have been in recent years under both the coalition government and also under the previous Labor Party government whose record on environmental issues—despite the great green credentials of people such as Senator Conroy, well-known tree saver that he is—nonetheless had a lot of room for improvement. The Democrats are very keen to use our role now with the balance of power to ensure that environmental issues are put much more on centre stage. We hope that we will be able to do that. I urge people to examine this report, because it is an important one. For that reason as well, I think it appropriate that it stays on the Notice Paper , so I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
