subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders: Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —On this day the Senate considered and passed a resolution affirming a wholehearted commitment on behalf of the national community to a process of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. This resolution was sponsored by Senator Hill on behalf of the coalition parties and by Senator Ridgeway on behalf of the Australian Democrats. On this same day the House of Representatives passed the same resolution sponsored by the Prime Minister.

speech.para: During the debate on the motion, a number of senators took advantage of the opportunity to express their views about it. In the interests of time, I did not seek to address the Senate at that time. However, insofar as Senator Ridgeway may be said to be a representative of the first peoples of Australia in this Senate, I may claim to have the role of a representative of the new peoples of this country. Therefore I would like, even though this matter has already passed and is established, to take this opportunity to put on record—on behalf of those Australians who became Australian by choice and those many more who will in future generations come to Australia and become Australian by choice—our support for the resolution and the process of reconciliation that it promotes.

I would also like to place on record the appropriateness and correctness, in our view, of the words and composition of the resolution, because it recognises a past history of injustice without being preoccupied by particular instances of injustice. Instead it focuses on the process of healing by which we as a nation must go forward. That this motion came at the right time is demonstrated by the senators from the various parties, representing all the people of Australia, who supported it. I note that, for example, Senator Boswell from the National Party, speaking on behalf of the bush, supported it. Of course, Senator Hill, who sponsored it, supported it. Senator Harradine supported it. Senator Harris, on behalf of One Nation, also supported it. I believe that this resolution, coming at such a time, reflects the national mood.

Having said that, I wish to place on record my immense disappointment with the way that the Australian Labor Party failed to adhere to the spirit of this proposal and sought to create further division by insisting on changes to certain wordings in the resolution. I note that Senator Ridgeway, in his speech proposing this motion, stressed that this should be a healing process and not politics—reflecting a sentiment by Dr Lowitja O'Donoghue that it should be a healing process and that politics should be out of it. And yet, as I said, I was intensely disappointed that the Labor Party chose to make a political issue out of it.

I wish that the Labor Party senators had been present in the house late yesterday afternoon to listen to the speech by Senator Mason—just preceding the first speech of Senator Ridgeway—which is perhaps the best reflection there could be of the mood of the nation in seeking reconciliation. I take this opportunity to commend Senator Mason on his words. I think that is all I need to say on this issue, having put my feelings on record.

talk.start.para: —In the Australian newspaper of last Thursday, 19 August appeared a series of timely, disturbing yet predictable articles on the poor state of government openness in Australia. The articles highlighted the lengths to which governments at both state and Commonwealth levels have gone to close the doors to public scrutiny of their dealings with the private sector. I have spoken earlier this year in the Senate of the scandalous use of the commercial-in-confidence cloak by this government—and other governments—to prevent examination by the Senate of various documents, and not least by this government on that matter.

speech.para: On that occasion, the federal government had claimed that it was Senate practice not to require the production of certain documents. The Senate, as one of the two houses which represent the people, may decide at its discretion that certain documents should not be made public, but it is not at the discretion of the executive that such a decision should be made. To do so is for the executive to usurp the crucial role of scrutiny of government that this house performs and that all parliaments perform as a democratic and public duty.

One of the reasons that I have raised this issue in the past—and will continue to raise it repeatedly in the future until something is done—is the horrendous cost incurred by governments' secrecy. In my home state of Western Australia, those costs were not limited to the hundreds of millions wasted in the WA Inc. saga but also extended to taxpayer funds subsequently spent on the royal commission and the Commission on Government. The valuable work done by those bodies now gathers dust, propping up library shelves. The Court government has barely even paid lip-service to their recommendations—which, incidentally, is in my view one of the reasons so many voters are disillusioned with it. There are millions of dollars being spent by that government under the cloak of secrecy, money that we will only find out about when it is too late. It is a great pity that the early promise of the Court government that it would clean things up and become much more accountable has been forgotten.

The Australian Democrats supported the recommendations of the Western Australian royal commission and those of the Western Australian commission of government. We endorse the two-pronged approach to freedom of information those bodies envisaged. We support the promotion of the freedom of information regime as the governing legislation for determining when information held by the government should be disclosed. But we also support the enactment of privacy legislation to address specific privacy issues surrounding the storage, use and retrieval of personal data and data-matching between government agencies.

The Western Australian royal commission in 1992 found that unnecessary secrecy surrounded actions taken by the government into some of the events into which the commission inquired. The government was found to have used official secrecy to keep the public deliberately uninformed. Openness in government is an indispensable prerequisite of accountability to the public. It is a democratic imperative. The right to vote has no substance unless it can be cast in an informed way based on adequate information. If government is to be government for the people, if the public is to be able to participate in government and experience its benefits, the public must be properly informed about government and its affairs. Openness will not, of course, hold for all purposes and in all circumstances, national security being an obvious example, but it should be the norm and secrecy should be the exception. Information is the key to accountability in government. In fact, it is the key to a democratic system.

The edition of the Australian to which I referred earlier also contained an editorial which succinctly puts the case for governments at all levels to lift their performance in this area. It read in part as follows:

Contracting out can reduce or extinguish the public's rights as otherwise assured by a range of laws, such as review by Ombudsman or judge, and freedom of information. It is through these laws that citizens keep governments and public authorities accountable. Parliaments, as well as individuals, are now less well informed. A number of auditors-general have complained of their inability to report fully to their Parliaments because of commercial confidentiality clauses in contracts between governments and the private sector. Yet Parliaments have a duty to scrutinise the business of Governments. And taxpayers, as the source of the funds used to pay for the rising number of contracts with private companies, are entitled to know how their money is being spent. Where the private sector replaces the public, the level of information available should not be reduced.

It would seem apparent that the primary reason the level of information has been reduced is that governments fear what may be brought to the public's attention. The former Victorian Auditor-General confirmed this in recently stating, `There's no doubt in my mind the desire to hide behind the shield of commercial confidentiality in some cases is a desire to hide commercially embarrassing situations rather than what's confidential.' Such a circumstance cannot be tolerated. It is the job of parliaments to seek out such situations and prevent or minimise the damage they might cause.

If responsible government is to have some real meaning in the Commonwealth of Australia and in each state, the constitutional role of the parliament must be discharged and be seen to be discharged. Accountability can be exacted only where those whose responsibility it is to call government to account are themselves possessed of, or are able to obtain, the information necessary to make considered judgments. Information is the key to ac countability. Governments consistently and persistently use commercial confidentiality to hide matters that should not be hidden, to conceal deals and arrangements that should be exposed, and to protect special, private and sometimes improper relationships from public scrutiny and accountability.

A challenge must be made to the arrogant use of executive power to maintain cloaked arrangements. In the unanimous High Court judgment in the 1997 Lange case, the High Court directly addressed the issue of the reach of executive power in the following terms:

Those provisions which prescribe the system of responsible government necessarily imply a limitation on legislative and executive power to deny the electors and their representatives information concerning the conduct of the Executive Branch of Government throughout the life of a Federal Parliament.
Thus the court highlights a constitutional limitation on the power of the executive to withhold information.

But it is not just the Constitution we must pay attention to in this matter. It is the duty of responsible government within a progressive democracy to have as little secrecy as possible in its affairs. Election results federally and in the states clearly reflect a desire by the Australian people to have independent upper houses that do act as a check on the executive. But in order to carry out this desire of the people, parliament must demand, and get, full disclosure on government dealings.

The Australian Democrats will continue to pursue this issue at every opportunity. This is one issue that will never fade from Australia's political agenda, no matter how much any government may want it to. In my opinion, the Australian newspaper did us all a service last week by drawing attention to this critical issue.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to highlight the importance of the tourism industry to Australia, and of course to my own state of Tasmania. Today at Parliament House we had a CSIRO national science briefing on Managing the Tourists: Regional Australia's Big Opportunity. Speakers were Professor Philip Pearce, Paul Walker and Sir Frank Moore, who gave enlightening addresses on cooperative research centres for sustainable tourism, the CSIRO tourism futures simulator and insights into the future of the Douglas Shire.

speech.para: Tourism is indeed exciting because of its potential to create jobs, increase national wealth and bring the world and Australia closer together. The Internet can bring the most obscure tourist site to the world stage. Australia is indeed a great place to visit. The friendliness of our people, the spectacular natural environment, the culture, the multicultural community, the food and wine, the lifestyle, the weather, the water—all have made Australia one of the most desirable destinations in the world.

The Tourist Commission has the task of promoting Australia to the world as a tourist destination, and it declares tourism's top 10 facts to be as follows. It employs 12 per cent of the work force. Many jobs are for young people and in regional areas. Over 200,000 new jobs are expected to be created in the next decade. $16.4 billion was received in foreign exchange earnings in 1997-98. The industry is Australia's largest single earner of foreign exchange dollars. It contributes 10.5 per cent to GDP and governments will receive over $16 billion in taxes generated by tourism in 1998. Foreign exchange earnings and taxes paid to governments are forecast to almost double over the next 10 years.

Inbound arrivals in 1998 were 4.2 million, actually a decline of 3.7 per cent on 1997, but there is growth of 3.4 per cent forecast for 1999. Growth between 2002 and 2007 is forecast to average 7.5 per cent per annum, reaching 7.7 million international visitor arrivals in 2007, when export earnings are forecast to grow to close to $30 billion. So, in world terms, Australia's market share and receipts from tourism are indeed improving.

But, when one reflects on these top 10 facts, it is very important to take into consideration that over 80 per cent of companies in the industry employ fewer than 20 people. Their employees make up around 50 per cent of the work force, so small business plays a very big part in Australia's tourist industry. The Productivity Commission estimates that for every 10 per cent increase in the number of visitors to Australia 30,000 jobs are created. Tourism has helped create 1.8 million new jobs in the service industries between 1984 and 1997.

It is interesting to note that the manufacturing, mining and agricultural industries combined created only 5,000 new jobs over the same period. Research which has been undertaken by Tourism Training Australia, which is responsible for tourism training throughout the country, estimates that in the 10 years between 1995 and 2005 the tourist industry will have generated up to 200,000 new jobs. The industry supports growth in services in the retail industry, manufacturing, the education system, entertainment and leisure.

In 1998 overseas tourist visitors from Japan recorded the highest number of arrivals to Australia, totalling 750,315. New Zealand was second, the UK was third, the USA was fourth and Singapore was fifth. Fifty-seven per cent of these people came to holiday, 20 per cent came to visit friends and relatives, 11 per cent came to conduct business, 10 per cent came for other purposes and the convention market attracted two per cent. It is quite interesting to look at their length of stay. For Europeans it was 38 days, 28 for Americans, 12 for Japanese, 27 for Asians and 13 for New Zealanders. The Japanese actually spent more per day on average, at $114, and the Europeans spent the least, at $61 per day, but each group visits different sorts of destinations. Popular places to visit included the Blue Mountains in New South Wales, theme parks on the Gold Coast, the Great Barrier Reef and the Phillip Island penguin parade. More visited Parliament House in Canberra, for example, than visited Kakadu—nearly double. In Tasmania, the Port Arthur historic site was particularly popular.

Australia is developing some exciting new products in Aboriginal tourism, wine and food, sports tourism and cruise shipping. The ultimate national showcase will be the 2000 Olympic Games next year and, according to the Tourism Forecasting Council, between 1997 and 2004 the Games will directly and indirectly bring an additional 1.6 million visitors and $6.1 billion in foreign exchange earnings to Australia. They are the single biggest tourism opportunities for Australia in our lifetime and are the biggest advertisements our country could hope for.

Of course, immediately following the Olympic Games the Paralympics will be held. There are some other big events at the start of the new century. For example, in 2001 Australia will celebrate the Centenary of Federation, in 2002 Sydney will host the Gay Games, in 2003 Australia will host the Rugby World Cup and in 2006 Melbourne is expected to host the Commonwealth Games.

While Australia receives an enormous number of visitors, there is still plenty of potential. The world's number one tourist destination in 1996 was France, with 70 million arrivals. The second was Spain with 48 million. The United States was third with 47 million short-term visitors.

The federal government has granted the Australian Tourist Commission an additional $50 million over the four years from 1998-99 and the funds will be used in part to boost activities in Europe and North America and to allow the development of these emerging markets. Australia is promoted in many and varied ways in all corners of the world. We are defining our personality—building and selling an image of Australia to the world. But one of the key issues facing Australian tourism is the issue of dispersal, getting visitors to venture outside the major destinations of Sydney, Melbourne, the Gold Coast, Brisbane, Far North Queensland, Adelaide, Perth and of course Canberra.

Approximately one-fifth of visitors venture beyond those places and, fortunately for my state of Tasmania, that figure is growing. We have great potential in Tasmania. North America registered the most visitors to Tasmania in 1998 with 27 per cent, followed closely by the United Kingdom with 25 per cent, continental Europe with 21 per cent and Japan ranked sixth with four per cent. One only has to go into some of our national parks, such as Cradle Mountain or Freycinet, to hear tourists speaking with great enthusiasm about the extraordinary beauty of these areas.

Interestingly, we found that the North Americans stayed, on average, for eight nights in Tasmania, spending on average $125 per day—of course, money goes a lot further in Tasmania. The British stayed, on average, for 15 nights and spent $76 on average per day. People from continental Europe stayed for an average of 18 nights, spending about $62 on average per day. Major attractions for all visitors to Tasmania—including domestic tourists—included the Port Arthur historic site, Salamanca Place in Hobart, the Cataract Gorge in Launceston, Cradle Mountain, Mount Wellington, Coles Bay, the Freycinet Peninsula on the east coast and the Gordon River on the west coast.

The future for Australian tourism is bright. No other industry has the potential to create more jobs over the next 10 years. Tourism spending impacts right across the country and provides jobs for over one million people. The industry and government are working together to grow tourism. By bringing the world to Australia we bring national income, cultural ties, employment and an opportunity for Australians to celebrate their country and to confirm what the rest of the world thinks—that we are the most welcoming and friendliest country on earth.
